In the recently released Report on Government Services , a number of interesting and pertinent statistics are presented that clearly show that property crimes, such as armed and unarmed robbery, are increasing in certain states over the period 1993 to 1997 and are stable or decreasing in other states.

answer.para: If I might, I will choose my own state of South Australia, since the question comes from Senator Ferguson, and Australia's `Premier' state, New South Wales, for comparison of rates of armed and unarmed robbery, two crimes that are very closely related to the use of illegal drugs. In 1993, the rate of unarmed robbery in South Australia was 82.9 per 100,000 of population, but by 1997 this had dropped to 57.4 per 100,000, a decrease of 31 per cent in five years in South Australia. No doubt this was due to fine police work and a good Liberal government. By stark contrast, the rate of unarmed robbery in New South Wales over the same period increased from 61.5 per 100,000 to 121 per 100,000, an increase of 97 per cent over the same time. So unarmed robbery goes down by 31 per cent in South Australia and soars by 97 per cent in New South Wales.

If we turn to armed robbery, the picture is even more disturbing. New South Wales and South Australia started roughly neck and neck in 1993 at 38.6 and 33.5 armed robberies per 100,000 of population but, as the full effects of the Carr government's failed law enforcement policies began to take hold, New South Wales accelerated to a frightening lead with 79.3 armed robberies per 100,000, an increase of 105 per cent over that same time period. This is three times the Victorian figure for armed robbery in 1997. South Australia, on the other hand, declined to a modest 25.3—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise is unacceptable. It makes it impossible for people listening, either on radio or television, to hear what is being said.

—The rate in South Australia declined to a modest 25.3, a decrease of 34 per cent over the same five years. So armed robbery was up by 105 per cent in New South Wales and down by 34 per cent in South Australia. These startling statistics show that there are ineffectual law enforcement policies in New South Wales under the Carr Labor government. It has utterly failed the people of New South Wales, who must now live in constant fear for their person and property. I am told that there are so many bars on some windows in Sydney that you are not sure if you are in a prison or a zoo, and it should not be that way.

answer.para: To be fair, I might add that rates for murder and attempted murder—if I do not get there, Senator Ferguson—in New South Wales are quite in line with the national average, demonstrating again it is the failed drug policies of the Carr government that have allowed property crime to escalate to rates twice the national average. I repeat what I said the other day: Premier Carr has shown himself to be not interested enough to do something about this. He should put up or shut up.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet Seminar

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister explain why the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is supporting a seminar on women in leadership featuring Ms Kerry Chikarovski in Sydney on 25 March this year, just two days before the New South Wales election?

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right will cease shouting.
—What, do you want Carmen Lawrence?
—Senator Abetz!
—Does the minister believe it is appropriate for the senior department of the Commonwealth Public Service to be lending its support to the Liberal Party in this way?
—I would understand why they would use Ms Chikarovski in a seminar on women in leadership—
—Yes, there's a state election two days later!
—Order! Senator Ray, stop shouting.
—Firstly, because she is a woman and, secondly, because she has fine leadership qualities. In relation to the role of the Department of PM&C, that is something upon which I will seek advice.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister also inform the Senate as to precisely what support Prime Minister and Cabinet is providing for these seminars which, apart from promoting Ms Chikarovski on the eve of the New South Wales election, feature other Liberal luminaries such as Senator Newman and Mrs Kate Carnell?

—I understand that too because they are a further two fine women leaders within Australian politics. Mrs Carnell has led the ACT in difficult circumstances and in a commendable way. We all know Senator Newman is a fine minister and represents ably not only her sex but also Australian politics generally. I am pleased that you have given me the opportunity to endorse all three women today, Senator. We are proud to stand behind them as fine representatives of the Liberal Party in politics. Senator Vanstone should have been included as well. If it is not too late, we will see if we can make arrangements.
—I have a busy schedule.
—And use public funds to promote the Liberal Party.
—I am sorry, I understand she had prior commitments, otherwise she would have been invited.
—Nick wouldn't put you on the list!
—Order! The Senate will come to order! The behaviour is absolutely unacceptable, and all sides are in breach of the standing orders.
—As I have already said in relation to the role of PM&C, I will ask.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, and I refer to the recent elections for the new World Heritage Bureau. Can the minister tell the Senate whether it was he as minister for the environment or Mr Downer as Minister for Foreign Affairs who ordered the Australian delegation in Kyoto to lobby against the election of the Thai ambassador to the seven-member World Heritage Bureau? On what basis was the order given to the Australian delegation to lobby against Thailand?

—I would be surprised as to the accuracy of that, Madam President. Thailand has a real interest in these matters and is currently on the World Heritage Committee—and, I am sure, contributing capably to that task. I would suggest that the honourable senator should not believe everything that falls off a truck.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. This did not fall off the back of a truck; this was a cable dated 23 December from Kyoto to Canberra. I ask again: can the minister inform the Senate whether the Australian government has organised to have the Thai ambassador dumped because he strongly reminded the committee of its world heritage obligations and further reminded the committee that a world heritage site can be placed on the in danger list without the consent of the state party?
—I thank the honourable senator for doing her bit to enhance Australia-Thai relations by relating what would appear to be a cable that she has found after it fell off the back of a truck.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order, and it is one of relevance. I asked the minister whether it was he or Minister Downer, and I wonder if you would direct the minister to answer that question?
—The minister is dealing with the topic. If he wishes to say something on that particular matter, he may.

—I was just going to acknowledge this latest attempt by the Australian Democrats to undermine Australia's international relations, which builds upon their attempt to undermine the Australian government position by lobbying the Kyoto committee directly. It reminds me of when former Senator Kernot, in relation to climate change, wrote to the chairman of the committee and said, `Don't believe the Australian government.' The Australian Democrats have an appalling way of dealing with these international relations matters, and I think Senator Allison should reflect upon what she is doing.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. I ask whether the minister can confirm that on Tuesday his department emailed a press released entitled `Government confirms commitment to new oil code', which said:

question.para: The government will be releasing the draft oil code by the end of this week and the petroleum repeal bill will not be effective until the oil code is prescribed in regulation.
Can the minister also confirm that his department yesterday emailed a follow-up note saying:
A draft media release entitled `Government confirms commitment to new oil code' was inadvertently emailed to you yesterday afternoon. Please disregard the release.
Minister, why should the media disregard the release? Is the government committed to an oil code or not? Will the government be developing policy in future by using inadvertent press releases?

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Conroy very much for the opportunity to announce that the government has released today a comprehensive draft oil code for discussion purposes. I did have a dorothy dixer lined up, but I thank Senator Conroy very much for giving me the opportunity to use a question from the opposition to announce the release of this draft oil code.

answer.para: This is very much a part of our comprehensive reform of petrol legislation. We will be repealing the two relevant pieces of legislation, and there is a repeal bill currently before the parliament. We made a commitment at the time of the election that the repeal of those two pieces of legislation would not take place until an agreed oil code had been tabled as regulations to the Trade Practices Act.

talk.start.para: —So both sides have agreed to the code?
—Order! Senator Schacht, you can follow it up later.

—We have devoted enormous resources to developing that oil code under the leadership of Rogers QC and extensive negotiation. That oil code is now at a point where, as I say, it has been released today. It has been sent to all relevant parties. I have just signed letters to all the participants in this debate giving them the oil code and asking them to come back to the government within three to four weeks with any further comments they have on that oil code.
—It's not agreed. This is just another draft. You've just released another draft—that's about five already.
—Senator Schacht, cease interjecting!

—I asked them to participate in the consultation phase with a spirit of compromise to ensure that we do get a satisfactory and workable oil code which will protect the interests of the small players. All senators and members in this parliament would have a legitimate and proper concern for the interests of the smaller players in this industry. That is why we want to put out and get entrenched into the Trade Practices Act a workable oil code which will protect their interests. The repeal of the franchise act and the sites act will not take place until that oil code is agreed and put into the Trade Practices Act as a consistent set of regulations.
—It's just another draft!
—Senator Schacht, cease shouting!
—Thank you, once again, Senator Conroy, for giving me this opportunity to formally announce the release of the draft oil code.

—My question is to my Tasmanian colleague the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. This week marks the 10th anniversary of the Burdekin report being made public. Given the Howard government's continuing commitment to improving the social and economic welfare of young Australians, will the minister advise the Senate what progress has been made in the vital areas of youth homelessness?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Calvert for his question. It has been 10 years since the Burdekin report was brought down, and now is really a valuable time to stand back and look at what has been achieved. Our government, when it came into office three years ago, put youth homelessness at the top of its priorities for social policy programs and policy development. We well understand the problems that are faced in our communities by the break-up of families and the homelessness that sometimes is produced as a result. The Burdekin report made very clear the social problems the nation faces as a result of youth homelessness.

answer.para: You can contrast the approach of this government with that of the Hawke and Keating governments, both of which were very much focused on the ambulance at the bottom of the cliff rather than the fence at the top of the cliff. We have introduced a concerted attempt to make prevention rather than bandaids the priority of this government in terms of young people who are at risk of homelessness.

When we first came into government, the Prime Minister called together the major welfare organisations and set up a task force to work in cooperation with three of the major federal departments to try to establish a pilot program to prevent youth homelessness and help those who were homeless. Following the evaluation late last year of that pilot program, which has been a great success—and I think those senators who have had anything to do with it would recognise that—the Prime Minister launched a new $60 million program to combat youth homelessness with a focus on early intervention. At the heart of that, we are recognising the need to try to keep families together wherever possible, because the research does show that early intervention is a really important way of preventing young people becoming trapped in the cycle of homelessness and long-term welfare dependency.

An independent evaluation of the pilot program showed that reconciliation was achieved between the parents and young person in 72 per cent of the cases, and improvements to relationships and greater stability also resulted from these reconciliations. The program is designed to encourage the young to reconcile with their families and re-engage with education, training and employment in the community, which are the linchpins as we all know to a whole and meaningful life.

This new program, now with the extra funding, will assist thousands of Australian families each year, including about 7,000 young people and 5,000 parents. When it is fully operational, there will be 100 services funded across Australia targeting areas of highest need at a cost of $20 million a year. That is, of course, only part of what this government is doing to attack the problems that were identified in the Burdekin report. For example, $230 million this financial year is going into the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, which is helpful for those who are already homeless. The government has also allocated $13.8 million this year for the Job Placement, Employment and Training program. But the Burdekin report also very significantly identified the lack of literacy skills as an important thing that needs to be overcome in these young people who are showing up as unemployed and homeless. Few of them have the qualifications necessary to gain employment. That is why we have put such a priority on helping young job seekers who have been unemployed for six months to focus on and access the money that is available for literacy and numeracy programs. We have to get their skills up so they are able to get a job.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have some information for Senator Gibbs, who asked a question yesterday about the child disability assessment tool and its affect on customers. I promised to look at the detail and report back. The figure of 3,800 was the original estimate of the number of children who would not qualify their parents for child disability allowance in a full financial year. As the new assessment arrangements for child disability allowance were introduced on 1 July 1998, it is too early to assess their full impact on the number of recipients. Once this information is available, I will provide it.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business (Senator Alston) to questions without notice asked of him today.

What we had yesterday was the unedifying sight of a Commonwealth minister releasing in a complete blind panic very thick documents stamped `cabinet-in-confidence' and `highly protected' throughout the press gallery and to anyone who was interested in them. You have to ask yourself why Minister Reith took this course of action. It was not, of course, to protect the national interest. It was not, of course, to protect the integrity of any government papers or documents. It was simply to try to dilute the effect of those documents on the media and the public. You also have to ask yourself whether that is now going to be the way the government reacts in relation to a whole number of things at Senate estimates committees and at question time. Will the government say, `That is a matter of cabinet-in-confidence and is certainly something the Senate should not be pursuing'?

What these documents do conclusively is show the untruths and the deliberate misleading of the Australian electorate in the 1996 and 1998 federal election campaigns by the Prime Minister and Mr Reith. These documents graphically highlight that the Prime Minister never intended to give the sorts of promises we talked about at question time today—on the no disadvantage test, the award safety net and the protections offered to workers in this country.

There are many other things that these documents show. What about the fact that the Minister for Family and Community Services put out a very rushed press statement this morning saying that she `deplores the misrepresentation of Mr Reith's paper by the opposition,' and that `Mr Reith did not seek to impose limits on the duration of income support for the unemployed.' That is a deliberate attempt to mislead the Australian public, because if you go to page 11 of this cabinet-in-confidence document, Mr Reith says:

There would be merit in considering whether this Mutual Obligations approach could be applied to all adults once their receipt of allowance extends beyond, say, six months. I have in mind that beyond this duration, continued receipt of allowance could be conditional on the recipient being engaged in useful education activity, community service or other productive workplace activity.

Either Mr Reith or Senator Newman is not telling the truth. It is an open-and-shut case in this regard. The real situation is that, again, Senator Newman has been treated like a mushroom by the Prime Minister and Mr Reith. Her department has not been in the loop on this. They have had no involvement. This extraordinarily rushed press statement was put out this morning in the press gallery to try to ensure that the damage is minimised.

If you look closely at this cabinet-in-confidence document, you see what Mr Reith is all about, because this document says a lot about the relations between the minister for employment and the Prime Minister. You have to ask a very important question: has anyone ever heard from a minister of state a more grovelling, cringing, toadying and obsequious comment than the sort of thing we see in this document? Let me quote what Mr Reith said to the Prime Minister:

For what it is worth, my assessment is that if the electorate will accept your lead on the GST then there is no reason to think that you could not successfully present and implement a genuine jobs plan.
Who said it? The sycophantic utterings of none other than Mr Reith—Penthouse Pete. Is he a man or a mouse?

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Faulkner!
—He is a landlord.
—Senator Faulkner, could I ask you to withdraw personal imputations against the minister and use the correct title for him, please.
—What would you like me to withdraw, Madam Deputy President? I withdraw the fact that I said `man or mouse'.
—No, I would request you to withdraw your unparliamentary language—
—I withdraw any unparliamentary language that I have uttered.
—Thank you—and refer to ministers by their correct title.
—Penthouse Pete is a nickname and should be used in this chamber.
—It is a well-known fact.
—Order! Senator Ray and Senator Carr.

—If I should not use `Penthouse Pete', I will withdraw it. What I want to say is this document really goes to the state of the virulent, poisonous relationships in the leadership dogfight—and I use the word advisedly—in the Liberal Party. That is a canine word I actually can use.
—That is parliamentary.
—The interjections are not.
—This is where this government finds itself just a few months after the election. What a commentary on the state of play in the Australian government. (Time expired)

—One of the most riveting outcomes from the last election, if I may say so, has been the disintegration of any ideas in the Labor Party. About all that the Labor Party can do is to sneak about, try to find a document, something past, try to find somebody who has leaked and then come along to the Senate and be critical of the minister who is trying genuinely to talk about real issues in the community and in particular what is happening to jobs.

speech.para: I do not really know what is wrong with the opposition and what they have against really discussing unemployment in this country. It is just extraordinary that none of those on the other side appear to be capable of having a sensible discussion about properly thought-out national goals on the unemployed. All they can do is look backwards into the past and be a reactionary bunch who cannot look forward to the future. They cannot look forward to the fact that, if we actually get together and try to discuss some of these issues, there can be some real advantage to the unemployed in Australia.

The Labor Party has become such a vacant lot, such a policy free zone, and all you can do is write books. You cannot write down a policy; you are incapable of writing down a policy. You scrub policy and all you can do is to write books. What is it about the opposition that has made you shut down any ideas? Why are you so frightened of having a policy? What is wrong with having a policy on the unemployed? Why are you so hostile to ideas? It is far too important a subject to be simply quibbled about in question time. It is not much wonder that the public out there are disillusioned with the way in which both sides of politics are behaving when it comes to debate in this House on matters that affect so many people.

Having put absolutely nothing forward yourselves, not only can you not actually articulate a policy on unemployment but also you cannot even cooperate to look, in a proper review mode, at job creating policies that the coalition is bringing forward. There is no doubt that the ABS labour force figures that came out last week are encouraging, but there is a lot more that can be done. I don't think there would be anyone who would suggest that there is not.

No-one suggests that there should not be further labour market reform to get jobs for all Australians. Certainly, that is what Mr Latham seems to be suggesting. And, like it or not, Mark Latham is right when he said—I quote from the AustralianFinancial Review last year—`Those in the Labor Party know that Australia has a unique opportunity to improve the flexibility of its labour market.'

But those opposite do not seem to be taking much advantage of the fact that there might be a little chip there, a little encouragement, and that you have an opportunity to accept some responsibility to cast a vote for or against lower unemployment in Australia. So far, you have fallen at the first fence because you have not only refused to pass the unfair dismissal law but also repealed the regulation. And, in the words of small business, the legislation is worth more than 50,000 jobs. I do not know how you can live with that outcome.

Not only that, but you are now refusing—you could support it if you wished—to preserve the youth wage structure legislation. We all know that this will protect the jobs of some 225,000 young Australians. If you were sincere, if you were fair dinkum, if you had any concern about the future of young unemployed people in Australia, you would stop worrying about cabinet documents and you would start trying to come up with a policy—if you don't agree with ours—which might at least not be beneath contempt. You have had three chances. You have knocked off one of them. You could do something for the young unemployed. The other thing you could do is pass the GST package and create a better economic environment for jobs.

talk.start.para: —I start my contribution by expressing my disappointment that Senator Coonan didn't comment on policy, but rather said that she believes Labor lacks it. The only policy point Senator Coonan made was that she thought the GST should be introduced. Mr Reith's statement highlights the cynicism the Australian public feels with respect to the GST. That cynicism is highlighted by Mr Reith's references to New Zealand. He talks about the 500,000 jobs we would have had, had we gone down the same path as New Zealand. We know what happened in New Zealand—the GST was introduced there and welfare was cut. So why do you think we are cynical when we see a document such as this that refers to every other possible avenue Minister Reith can think of to cut, cut, cut? That is not policy.

speech.para: Let me highlight one area which reinforces that point. Minister Reith refers to the OECD 10 points and tries to redefine himself to fit in with them. That redefinition is very interesting when you look at OECD point 7, which says that countries `should emphasise an active labour market policy or policies'. How does Mr Reith describe that? Mr Reith describes that as `reform of labour market programs' because reform to Mr Reith is nothing but cut, cut, cut—cut rights to unfair dismissal, cut junior rates, et cetera.

I go back to Senator Hill's comments, since he has remained with us today, in response to Senator Harradine's question. Senator Harradine was concerned about the report in this morning's Australian which said that the Prime Minister had redefined his election commitment as only relating to existing employees. Senator Harradine sought clarification on that point. He got no clarification from Senator Hill. All Senator Harradine got was a re-reading of the election policy platform. Senator Hill, can you reassure us that the Prime Minister has not come out and said that it will only apply to existing employees? That was Senator Harradine's concern. That was the issue Senator Hill did not answer. We got no guarantee from Senator Hill that the Prime Minister was not referring only to existing employees. Senator Hill did not reassure us on that point at all.

Senator Newman was the only other minister here today who actually made some comment on the policy issues. She tried valiantly to demonstrate that she had actually been consulted. Unfortunately, she failed dismally. The one ounce of reassurance we had were her comments in question time today that unemployment figures will not be redefined to rule out people on Work for the Dole. What a bodgie, rorting system this government is looking at if they are looking at forcing all unemployed onto Work for the Dole and then redefining them as employed.

I want to conclude on a point that highlights exactly what Minister Reith is talking about. On page 12 of his statement he says that what he envisages as the employer-employee relationship would be established and employers would have the right to expect work of an acceptable standard. `The scheme would thereby be easier to administer with non-compliance resulting in termination of payment.' So we will now have employers determining whether workers on Work for the Dole payments have their payments terminat ed if they are not working hard enough. That is sheer slavery. Mr Reith is talking about sheer slavery. That is what he is describing in this program—nothing more, nothing less. It is dismal that members of the government here today can make no contribution to this policy debate except for Senator Newman's reassurance that they will not be cut off the unemployment figures. That is the only reassurance we have had on policy issues in this debate today.

talk.start.para: —I want to start today by quoting a couple of lines I have here that go back to 1990.
—Oh, you have come in today, have you?

—I have been in every day, I think, Senator Faulkner. With respect to the allegation Senator Collins just made that we take people from the unemployed and put them onto Work for the Dole and that then reduces unemployment, of course it does. Any form of work reduces unemployment. But that is a lot better way to enter the 21st century than the Labor Party could ever do. The Labor Party is expert in the employment of labour. Do you know what your former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, the mafia millionaire, said? On 20 February 1990, in contrast to our approach, he said:

speech.para: We've got to go now and intensively interview them, make `em apply for work, and if they don't apply for work we'll bump `em off.

What a disgraceful thing to say about unemployed people! Once people become unemployed, in your view, they cease to be important because you do not get union dues out of them. I know that because of the unions that I have belonged to. You do not get union dues out of them when they are unemployed. They cease to become important. That is why unions are dropping below 30 per cent in work forces. That is why you are losing them.

Let me go on. Under your administration unemployment reached the highest—Senator Collins quoted the OECD—level in the OECD. Unemployment in Australia under your administration reached the highest level in the OECD. It is now down to 7.5 per cent—not the lowest in the OECD but one of the lowest in the OECD. Certainly a long way from the 11½ per cent it was under you people. You had the temerity to criticise this administration for bringing unemployment down. I do not know what you are going to do. You are not doing too well now, but when Senator Robert Ray leaves you shortly, sometime through this term, certainly at the end of this term, the IQ will drop by about 50 per cent on the other side. What is going to happen then?

The problem is that there is a focus on the other side on the wrong areas. The focus has to be on the unemployed. This government is committed to bringing unemployment down. It has brought it down. It is performing. It is an abysmal lack of action on your part. You left us with high unemployment. You left us with high interests rates. The government is doing everything in its power, and it is doing it properly and methodically. I do not know how the documents were leaked. You are concentrating on the documents. Why do you not concentrate on some policy that helps your fellow Australians that are unemployed? Why do you not do that? Why do you not join with us? You do not have policies in this area, and this is one area where you should have some expertise. But you do not even have any expertise in the unemployment area. You do not offer anything. You criticise, but you do not offer anything.

It is not complete blind panic, as Senator Faulkner said. It is a studied way from the Prime Minister through his ministers through his cabinet to bring down unemployment, to sustain it at a level that is acceptable. There is no question that we will always have some unemployment, but there must be some acceptable level. This government is doing precisely that with a combination of low interest rates and low rates for business. If you people had voted through the acceptance of the small business package, where we would have employed 40,000 to 50,000 more people, we would have brought unemployment down to a lower figure than what it is now.

talk.start.para: —Senator Coonan said the Labor Party was hostile to ideas, but what is absolutely obvious from Senator Alston's answer to me today is that he is hostile to scrutiny. The one thing this government hates is for its actions, its administration and the decisions it makes of an administrative nature to be scrutinised. The government hates it. It has this obsession with saying, `All we ever want to do in this chamber is discuss ideas and policy.' That is a role for this chamber, but our duty and an equal role for this chamber is to scrutinise the actions of this government, to make sure probity is there, to make sure there is an ethical approach to government.

speech.para: In relation to the opinion polling for the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, it is a sleazy, stinking rort and nothing more than that. I put questions on notice to all departments. I asked how much work they have given to Mark Textor. Eleven departments have answered but not this department, even though the research was done in June/July last year. They have deliberately obstructed because the answer is embarrassing.

All the departments know. All the whispers are there. The departments are being strongarmed to give Mark Textor work. Why? Not only is he the Liberal Party pollster; the more work he gets, the nearer a critical mass to a credible polling organisation he becomes. He is not credible out there in the commercial world. They do not give him work. So he relies on his work from the Liberal Party and government departments. That is where he gets his work from. Senator Alston said this is just spite from us because Mark Textor got the last election right. No pollster got the election more wrong than Mark Textor. The Bulletin employed him, and his figures, as every other polling organisation knows, were absolute nonsense.

talk.start.para: —I thought you said he couldn't get any commercial work.

—He had you, Senator Ferguson, 15 points in front at one stage. If that is the case, we must have run the most magnificent campaign in history to reduce that 15-point margin to actually lead you on election day in primary and preferred votes. The fact is that Mark Textor's research is not worth the paper it is written on. If you go back to this document, this now tabled leaked cabinet-in-confidence document, you will never see more pathetic qualitative polling than the results shown there. The methodology is trash. The results in interpretation are incompetent.

speech.para: All you are doing is propping this person up, with his snout in the trough, strongarming contracts across to the Textor organisation when they should be going to competent polling firms. Let us have a look at his record. The Bulletin got rid of him after six weeks because he was so wrong. If you look at his track record in the Northern Territory, he leaked all the government paid research over to the Country Liberal Party. All of it went to them, illegally, in breach of copyright and in breach of contract. Let us look at whom he has allied himself with now. This is the great freedom loving Liberal Party with principles. Their pollster is part of Wirthlin, and Wirthlin is connected to every right-wing ratbag group in the United States that exists. They align themselves with the anti-Semites, with the white supremacists, with the flat-earthers and the gun-toting rednecks. That is their record in the United States. Sure, they do some work for the Republican Party but only to destroy other Republican moderates. Not even the Democrats are their enemy in the US; moderate Republicans are their enemy.

Questions need to be answered. How indeed did Textor get this contract? Given the fact that he did his research in July and given his track record in the Northern Territory how much of this research went to the Liberal Party before the election? The fact is that it took him four months to report to the department with this research. You can bet it got up to Robert Menzies' house a lot quicker. This ethical position that we have of Textor being strongarmed in and basically doing the Liberal Party's research is a national disgrace. We will not be bluffed out of scrutiny in this place. No matter how many dirges you go on with, we will be there scrutinising the actions of this government and exposing it when it is involved in corruption.

talk.start.para: —The first thing to say about Peter Reith's views on progressing reforms in the paper that we have all now well and truly seen and read is that this is a minister who has always pushed the envelope of industrial reform. He has always been at the forefront, and he has previous form on the board—so much so that he has, in fact, impressed Cheryl Kernot and the Democrats enough to get his first tranche of industrial reform through the parliament. His form on the board is now coming through, the success is coming through, in the statistics.

speech.para: First of all, he was the minister and we are the government that introduced a more flexible enterprise bargaining regime of three streams, three choices and options, for wage agreements. The attractiveness of that reform is shown in the figures. More than 45,000 AWAs have been approved, and 90 per cent of those have been in the last year. It has taken more than a year for those reforms to filter through, but they are coming through now. The attractiveness of AWAs is now showing through in the figures. Some 7,500 certified agreements have been made, including some 805 non-union agreements, covering around 100,000 workers. And there is still the award system, and there is still, underpinning that, the no-disadvantage test. From that, we have the low paid workers still receiving wage increases of more than five per cent through the Industrial Relations Commission, so there is a real wage increase.

Peter Reith was at the forefront of that very successful change. He is the minister who has overseen the unfair dismissal legislation, which has come through here. There was no reform held up more by the previous government than unfair dismissal. It was held up for ridicule. They know it themselves. They wanted to change it themselves prior to the 1996 election, yet when it came into this parliament they were against that particular reform—an area that of course, particularly for small business, deterred employment.

Another change introduced in the first tranche of our industrial relations reform was the secondary boycott. It had a positive effect. We reintroduced legislation—45D and 45E— about secondary boycotts. It had a positive effect on economic activity, that flowed on to employment. And where would we be if we did not have those clauses reintroduced into this parliament? Where would we be in relation to the waterfront dispute that we had last year? We would be right back to the bad old days. That one single change, introduced by Peter Reith, had the greatest effect down on the wharves to bring about change. We would be still living under the extortions, the strikes, the expenses and the rorts that were going on down on the waterfront. Now we have a revolution; we have world's best practice occurring down on the Melbourne waterfront. The union told us that they could not meet the container lifts rate. They were the worst in the world at 18 an hour; we were only asking for 25 an hour in our reforms. They are now reaching, at times, 32-plus down on the Melbourne waterfront. And that is because, more than anything, we had the legislation prior to the disruption to win that dispute, and we had to win it.

talk.start.para: —But you lost it!

—No. Senator Carr, we know you were seen down there linking up with your old union mates, defending all the lies of the MUA, all the protection rackets of the MUA. The results of Peter Reith's reform are now being seen down on the Melbourne waterfront. Senator Harradine made a point about the umpire system being enshrined in Australian culture and in industrial relations.
—He's right.

—He may well be right about that. But, Senator Harradine and those on the other side of the House, what is also enshrined in Australian culture and industrial relations is freedom of association. That, more than anything, is what is enshrined in Australian culture and workplaces—the right to belong to a union or not. And that is a right you and your union masters wanted to take away from the workers. That was a right that Peter Reith reintroduced into our industrial relations system, and that is in fact very much working out there in the workplace. (Time expired)
—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education References Committee

talk.start.para: —Order! The President has received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate seeking variations to the membership of a committee.

interjection.para: That the following senators be appointed substitute members of the Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education References Committee for its inquiry into the employment incentive and education impacts of the Government's taxation reform legislation proposals and on the provisions of the bills implementing the proposed new tax system:
Senator Watson to replace Senator Synon for 4 March 1999
Senator McGauran to replace Senator Synon for 22 February 1999.

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Select Committee on a New Tax System on the economic theories, assumptions, calculations, projections, estimates and modelling which underpin the government's proposals for tax reform, contained in Tax reform: not a new tax, a new tax system , together with the Hansard record of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 25 November 1998, the Senate referred issues relating to the GST and the proposed new tax system to this select committee and to three references committees of the Senate. The select committee was instructed to undertake its inquiries in two stages.

In this initial stage, the inquiry has focused on a preliminary analysis of the economic modelling and projections underpinning the Howard government's tax package—known by the acronym, ANTS. The second stage of the inquiry will examine the broader economic effects of the government's taxation reform package, with regard to the fairness of the tax system, the living standards of Australian households—especially those on low incomes—the efficiency of the economy and future public revenues. The second stage of the inquiry will draw on the findings of the three related inquiries conducted by the references committees. The references committee inquiries are due to be completed by 31 March this year and the final select committee report is expected to be presented by 19 April this year.

The terms of reference of the committee's inquiry were advertised in the national press in December last year and submissions called by the end of January this year. The committee is continuing to accept submissions and, to date, has received over 1,300 submissions. To date, the select committee has conducted nine public hearings in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne. The intention is to conduct a further 12 hearings over the next month. In addition, a substantial number of public hearings are being conducted by the three references committees, as part of the separate inquiries.

The select committee reporting today heard 36 witnesses, some of them more than once, and sat for 61½ hours, including for five hours on Monday. The timetable, Madam Deputy President, is, indeed, very tight and getting our report out on time imposed, I believe, incredible strains and left insufficient time to seek a consensus among the committee. In the report, there may be some editorial mistakes which reflect this fact.

Having said that, I will turn to the findings of myself and my Labor colleagues. This committee has served for Australia a quite important purpose. Up until now, funded by a $20 million taxpayer-supported publicity campaign, Australians have heard the government's view about a GST. We have been force-fed on glossy documents, televi sion and newspaper advertising, the cheer squad that supports the government, and ministerial statements telling us all that the GST is good for us. Those statements have been wrapped around pseudo-truths with some political and economic assertions in them.

What this inquiry has done is expose many of those statements by the government as having no particular basis in fact or no particular basis in modelling or research. This report, for the first time, enables independent voices in Australia to model and test the assumptions that the government has put into the public domain and make findings which are now public, through this report. This report has enabled industry groups, community organisations and unions to express their views in an inquiry setting about the tax and about the impacts of the tax on their organisations and on Australians generally. The propositions that the government has put in public debate and which featured in its advertising during the last election have at last come under independent scrutiny and test.

The conclusion is that, if you looked at what the government has said, most Australians have not been told the truth. As I said earlier, there is no basis for much of what the government has said in modelling; no basis for much of what the government has said in research; and no basis for much of what the government has said in advice to the government from Treasury. The worst feature of all that is that Australian taxpayers' money has been used to broadcast that situation—despite the lack of evidentiary proof of the assertions the government was making.

Let me turn to the major findings made by Labor senators from the evidence in this inquiry. The primary claim that the government based its assertions on was that the tax system is broken and in need of repair. The significant test as to whether that is true or not is the ability of the tax system to generate revenues to meet the needs of the Commonwealth. The truth is that the Commonwealth budget is in surplus. The aggregate of all state budgets is in surplus. The tax system, thereby, is doing its job at this point. As well, the modelling that was produced by the Monash Centre established that the current system, in fact, will produce more revenue for future needs than the system proposed in the GST package called ANTS by the government. That is a significant finding. It is significant because some in the welfare sector have assumed support for a GST based on the belief that the government was right when it said that the current tax system will not produce that outcome. Independent modelling shows that view—the foundation for the whole reason for reform—not to be true.

The second important finding concerns the inflation rate. We were told that the inflation rate that would be produced by the ANTS package—the GST package—is 1.9 per cent. In fact, the real truth is that it will be more like four to five per cent when the GST is introduced. Let me take you through why that is the case. The Treasury figure of 1.9 per cent is the second year effect. That is what we were told. The first year effect, produced by Treasury, is 2.4 per cent. When you take housing and cigarettes and tobacco into consideration, it is 3.1 per cent. Based on the fact that, in New Zealand, only 70 per cent of the savings under their GST flowed through to consumers as benefits, the real impact in Australia would be between four and five per cent—not 1.9 per cent, but four and five per cent.

We were also told by the government that their package would increase economic growth. Those assertions were made by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. Treasury admits that this is an assumption. No Treasury modelling was done to establish that this is true. It was an assumption based on Econtech modelling—it was not done of the ANTS package but was done of an assumption that Econtech had made. Based on that, Treasury appropriated an assumption in this case. No advice has been given by Treasury to the government on quantitative assessments on economic growth. The government got no numbers advice on employment, unemployment and economic growth figures. That, too, is a finding that comes through in the evidence.

The other assertion is that the GST will produce jobs. I have to say, on the evidence, that there is not a job in it. Any jobs that are created by this package are not created by a GST. The expert economists who gave evidence were unanimous on the fact that jobs, if they occur, will be created by the fiscal stimulus provided by raiding the surplus. That is old-fashioned Keynesian stimulus of an economy, by making a fiscal injection. But the evidence also found that there will be job losses. If wages track the increases in the consumer price index, 100,000 jobs will be lost in the early years of the GST. If there is a delay in passing on savings—that is, savings by cuts to indirect taxes such as wholesale sales tax—15,000 jobs will be lost. Where will they be lost? They will be lost in states like Queensland and Tasmania. In what industries will they be lost? They will be lost in industries like tourism and education exports—industries that are growth industries in this nation, providing the area in which job expectations rise. It will be in those areas that jobs will be lost.

The accountants association gave evidence that the assertion that a GST is a simple tax is doubtful—that in fact the GST is a complex tax. They could not tell us how complex because they were not able to complete their own survey of the complexities in time to give that evidence to the inquiry. Will the GST promote exports? This is the advice given to Australia by the Minister for Trade. On Treasury's own evidence the exchange rate will rise. That will in fact limit the ability of this nation to export and, again, the industries of tourism and education exports—two of the fastest areas of growth in the economy—will be hardest hit.

We were not able to take a lot of evidence on the black economy, but what is also true is that in other countries where a GST applies the black economy is often rampant and bigger, in some cases, than is the case in Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I commence my remarks by thanking the secretariat, under Rob Diamond's secretary-ship, for the enormous work that they have put into this report and to the inquiry to date. Under short time frames they have managed to organise hearings and produce a report, and they have been working exceptionally long hours. I would like to acknowledge the tremendous effort that has been made by the secretariat in working to that time frame.

speech.para: I have just heard Senator Cook talk about the Labor Party's report. It is no wonder he talks about the Labor Party's report, because one of the reasons there was such a rush to produce this report was, by Senator Cook's own admission, that preparing the Labor Party report was his highest priority. The body of the report, which we all had to read, came second. That is why there was such a rush yesterday. I only want to make three major points in relation to this inquiry.

talk.start.para: —It's not fair.

—Senator Murray says, `It's not fair.' In a meeting I had with Senator Cook early yesterday morning, he said he had been working on the Labor Party report because that was his priority. That is exactly what he said to me.
—That was a private conversation.
—Order! Senator Sherry, you do not interject from outside the chamber.
—It was not a private conversation, Senator Sherry. We had a meeting.
—You have got a bad habit of repeating private conversations.
—Senator Sherry, do not interject outside.
—Keep your blood pressure down!
—Order!

—Firstly, the Labor Party came to this inquiry with a predetermined position. So what they have to say about the tax reform system is irrelevant. It does not matter what this inquiry hears from witnesses because the Labor Party's position was determined prior to their listening to the very first witness we heard. Their position on the matters that we have been hearing evidence on is quite irrelevant. Although I have only had half an hour to see the Labor Party findings—and I have just been looking briefly through them—in the executive summary of the findings there is no basis for the assumptions that they draw in relation to government assertions and committee evidence.

speech.para: Secondly, I have looked at the conclusions in the Democrat report and I have seen the evidence that the Democrats have supplied in that report in relation to those conclusions. The Democrats agree with the majority of the government's conclusions that are drawn from the ANTS package. The Democrats in their conclusions found that there was agreement by analysts on the revenue forecasts underpinning the government's tax reform. The Democrats accept that tax reform is necessary and required to repair the revenue base—that is, they accept the government's view that the current tax system is broken. We acknowledge that in our report.

They accept that the government's tax package will provide a more sustainable and secure revenue base for the states and territories—from a quick appraisal of their report, this is something not even mentioned by the Labor Party. Nowhere do they mention anything about the more sustainable and secure revenue base for the states and territories. Above all else, the Democrats in Senator Murray's report accept that the macro-economic effects of the tax package are positive. They accept that, from the evidence we have heard from all of the supposed experts who have come before our inquiry, the macro-economic effects of the tax package are positive. So in all of those areas we agree with the Democrats.

Senator Murray, as the Democrat senator on this inquiry, has come to the inquiry and the public hearings to listen to try to expand his knowledge so that some determination can be made. He did not come with the predetermined position that the Labor Party had that they will oppose the tax package in its entirety. The Democrats have come to the conclusion that they want to look at the evidence and draw their conclusions from that.

Unfortunately, from the government's point of view, the Democrats were not convinced by the bulk of witnesses who argued that food should remain in the tax base. In all of the modelling that was done by those eminent modellers—Professor Dixon, Professor Neil Warren, Professor Ann Harding, David Johnson from the University of Melbourne, Chris Murphy and anybody who came before our committee—every one of them said that food should remain in the package. Not one said that it should be exempt. The reason they said that and the key reason for the government's position in wanting to maintain food in the GST system is that, if you want to provide equity for low and middle income earners and welfare recipients, the most effective way of delivering equity is through the existing social security system where the compensation can be targeted to those people who really need it. That is where we differ from the Democrats.

While the evidence was overwhelming from all of the modellers that food should remain in the tax package, the position the Democrats have taken on food in their report is that they have chosen to exempt it because they say that is more equitable. Those experts who came before us said, `No, that is not the case. If you want to deliver effective compensation to low income earners, to low wage earners and to welfare recipients, do it through the system that has been designed to do it—that is, through the social security system.' We totally support that point of view, although unfortunately it is not a view that the Democrats have accepted.

In relation to all of those other matters that I spoke about, the Democrats agree with the government's position that the tax system is broken, not the report that Senator Cook has made. This is one of the remedies that we are going to use to make sure that we fix the tax system for good. It is also evident that, because of the Labor Party's pre-determined position in relation to outright opposition to this tax package—and I have had a brief look at their report—they choose only those assumptions and the results of modelling using the most unrealistic assumptions, particularly in relation to jobs and wage demands. International experience has shown and evidence was given to us that, when a value added tax or a goods and services tax has been introduced in other countries, it has not been followed by wage demands.

The income tax cuts that are delivered in this package more than compensate for any increase in the CPI. So wage and salary earners will have more take-home pay than they currently have. How can you possibly factor in wage demands when wage and salary earners are going to have a bigger take-home pay under this package than they currently have today? It is unrealistic for the Labor Party to suggest that wage demands will follow, regardless of what the ACTU and one of the other unions which gave evidence to us said. International evidence does not support it and neither does the evidence that was brought before the committee.

One of the reasons that has been used by the Democrats in particular in trying to justify the exemption of food rather than using the social security system to compensate low income earners is that at some stage in the future governments can take that away. They cite New Zealand as an example. The Labor Party in some of their questioning also cited New Zealand where the compensation package was reduced some time after the introduction of the GST.

Let me say that most people tend to forget that, if they use New Zealand as a case, New Zealand has a unicameral system of parliament. The government of the day can do what they like without any review by an upper house. If the day ever comes when a move is made to reduce compensation levels—I can only presume that the Democrats and the Labor Party will still be sitting in the Senate and I cannot presume that any of us will ever have a majority in the foreseeable future—can you imagine any scenario under which this Senate would allow compensation to be reduced from the current compensation that is being offered by the government in this package?

In our supplementary report we have tried our best to provide you with evidence that was not in the main body of the report which supports our conclusions. We have also used a wide variety of quotes from people who appeared before us in the inquiry. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to commence by thanking the President of the Senate for the additional finance and assistance she gave to the committee for the very complex modelling task we had before us. I do wish to concur with the earlier speakers in thanking the secretariat for operating under considerable pressure and for the printers in producing this on time. In doing so I must colour my thanks slightly by indicating that the page numbers of our report have been put out of sequence. Anyone reading this report had better follow the page numbers, not the pages. I would be grateful if further copies could be corrected accordingly. It will merely make the people think that the Democrats are more confused than some think otherwise.

speech.para: The other person that I particularly want to thank is my adviser. As you know, the Democrats have limited resources and particular note needs to be made of John Cherry. I want to turn to the chair of the committee. The conduct of the chair was very good in sometimes trying circumstances and he has been of great assistance to the proper conduct of the inquiry to date. I thank him accordingly. I thank the deputy chair for his input. I thank Senators Conroy and Ferguson for their occasional repartee which has enlightened and enlivened the committee.

I drew attention in an interjection to the fairness of Senator Ferguson's remarks about the chair paying more attention to the Labor Party report than to the report of the committee. I thought that was appropriate since the chair had already just about completed the secretariat's analysis and review. It was quite proper that he should then turn his attention elsewhere, but I am sure he will defend himself in due course.

I also want to thank the modellers—numbering around nine—whose professional input has been extremely helpful to the committee. Regardless of their particular political persuasions and inputs, they seem to me a class of people whose professionalism does credit to both their industry and themselves.

I draw attention to some of the conclusions delivered in my colleague Senator Ferguson's address. We have had conversations with Professor Harding, as you would expect, and our understanding of her views on food is that the jury is still out for her and that the issues of adequacy and permanency are very much at hand.

Turning to the report itself, it was necessary, because of the failure of the government to release any substantive modelling of their tax plan before the election, to have this committee do modelling. I think it has been a very unusual experience for the Senate to have to commission quite such extensive work. The findings have been more than interesting to all of us. As Senator Ferguson outlined, the coalition and Democrats have both concluded, based on the evidence put before us, that the tax reform plan is likely to have a small but positive impact on the economy—somewhere up to about a 0.2 per cent increase in consumer welfare, fairly cautiously defined. So tax reform on the economic margin appears to be worth doing.

The coalition and Democrat senators have concluded that the indirect tax base is declining and is in trouble and the matter is serious—a point backed up, I note, by Access Economics today. If we fail to fix that indirect tax base, by the year 2002 we will need a nearly $3 billion increase in sales tax rates to restore them to the 1995-96 level. On the basis of the evidence, the coalition and Democrat senators concluded that the fiscal stimulus from the package will boost employment in the short term by around 30,000 jobs. But we should note that the long-term result on the employment side seems to be negligible.

As I read their report, interestingly, the coalition—and I noticed that Senator Ferguson did not draw much attention to it—have now finally conceded in their conclusions the Democrat assertion that exempting food will not reduce the economic boost from tax reform. That is a fundamental finding for us because now all the attention is on equity and simplicity with regard to the food issue. So that is the common ground—the things that the coalition and the Democrats have agreed on—but I think the Labor Party has similar views on many of those areas.

The Democrats have reached a number of other conclusions based on the evidence. First, the government's stated impacts of a GST on households deliberately underestimates the impact on low income households and overestimates the impact on high income households. That conclusion was backed up by six university professors and the Australian Bureau of Statistics in evidence to the committee. All recommended that the government should have used the data from the Households Expenditure Survey to calculate the impact on different household cameos with different levels of spending and saving. The committee has unanimously agreed that the tax plan needs to be remodelled at the distributional end of things using the HES data, and that report is due on 1 April.

The other key evidence—key from our point of view—has been on the exemption of food on economic efficiency grounds. Both modelling reports to the committee from Peter Dixon and Chris Murphy concluded that a GST without food would deliver the same economic benefits as a GST with food, but on equity grounds all witnesses conceded that taxing food is regressive. Why? Because low income earners spend twice as much as high income earners on food as a percentage of income, so taxing food will hurt them more.

Even witnesses who support a tax on food—such as Neil Warren and Geoff Carmody—acknowledged not only that the government's compensation was inadequate but also that the government's compensation is fragile. We have seen today, with Minister Reith's expose of his plans for the future, the exposure of what may be seen to be a secret agenda by the coalition for the next term, which is welfare reform, as they conceive it, and glowing praise for the way in which New Zealand has gone.

We all know—and Senator Ferguson drew attention to it—that they introduced a GST in New Zealand in 1987. They introduced compensation and withdrew it three or four years later in 1991—a withdrawal which, I must say, was much promoted by the Business Round Table there. If this government is working to the same game plan, we have a real problem on our hands, and the problem relates to trust. The surveys of the Australian people indicate that they do not trust governments. It does not matter which government; they do not trust governments. It is very difficult to gainsay that because survey after survey says that. I do not trust this government or any other government to keep their compensation in place if they develop other priorities.

On those grounds, the marginal economic benefits of the tax plan are more than offset by the unfairness it will generate, and it will then fail the equity test, in our view, if food is kept in. As we have said consistently all along, the package gets a tick on economic efficiency—well, we have not said that all along, but we have worked it out from the evidence—but it gets a cross on equity and fairness; and that is a big cross. The evidence before the committee has confirmed our view on these issues.

Finally, the committee heard strong evidence about the impact of the GST on housing and inbound tourism. In my report, I have a few comments to make about the need for action in this area. I will draw your attention, if I may, to some of the conclusions we came to. We listed them as 1 to 10. We also provided a summary of the findings of the two key final modellers that the committee used—Peter Dixon's and Chris Murphy's various measures of how the GST looks with food in and food out.

The modelling before the committee concluded that the long-term macro-economic effects of the tax package are likely to be positive, albeit small, with increases in capital investment and traditional exports, a small but positive rise in economic welfare, a negligible effect on employment and negative effects on industries such as tourism, housing and personal services.

The job of Labor will be to persuade the Australian people that alternative plans would produce as good, or better, results on the tax revenue front, on tax reform, on GDP and on the equity areas which the government is addressing. Our job, we believe, is to accept that the government's intent is right but its package is wrong in substantial detail. Unless we can persuade you to change your mind on that, we will find it very difficult to take a position in support of your package—and food, of course, is a fundamental issue within that. So I look forward very much to working with my colleagues further in this matter, and I compliment both the chair and the deputy chair on what they have done to date. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I present the government's response to report No. 355 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Aboriginal councils and Torres Strait Island councils: Review of financial accountability requirements , and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

para.inline: Response to the Report by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA)
ABORIGINAL COUNCILS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLAND COUNCILS: REVIEW OF FINANCIAL ACCOUNTABILITY REQUIREMENTS

speech.para: June 1998
FOREWORD

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) " Report 355: Aboriginal Councils and Torres Strait Island Councils: Review of financial accountability requirements" was tabled in Parliament on 27 November 1997.

In its report JCPA made 19 Recommendations of which Recommendations 2, 3, 4, 12, 14, 15, and 16 had policy implications. As ATSIC is the agency with prime carriage of these issues the response has been prepared by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs after convening an Interdepartmental Committee with representatives from:
Department of Finance and Administration
Department of Health and Family Services
Department of Transport and Regional Development—National Office of Local Government
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission—Queensland State Manager. The Torres Strait Regional Authority sent a position paper.
Apologies were received from Prime Minister and Cabinet.
The Australian National Audit Office participated in the discussions although not as a Commonwealth Government Representative.
The representatives concurred with the response.
The report is hereby tabled.

para.inline: The establishment of a Grant Providers Forum at Ministerial level comprising representatives of the Commonwealth and Queensland Government agencies funding the councils, together with representatives of the Aboriginal Coordinating Council and the Island Coordinating Council

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives of the IDC do not support the recommendation to establish a separate Grant Providers Forum at Ministerial level. There are a number of forums already in existence where these matters can be dealt with, for instance the Ministerial Council on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (MCATSIA) and Health Minister's Forums.
However, merit is seen in establishing some Regional Grant Providers Forums to ensure the program responsibilities are implemented appropriately (see comments under Recommendation 4).
Discussions held between ATSIC and the Queensland State government indicate that there was no interest in a separate
Ministerial forum.

para.inline: (a) develop standardised grant procedures and acquittal processes, which satisfy the requirements of the major stakeholders.

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives of the IDC agree in principle with the report's findings in relation to the need for standardisation of procedures across agencies provided that various legislative requirements can be met. However, it was felt that advances may be achieved only in the longer term.

ATSIC has recently undertaken a major review of its grant procedures and modified them in line with the Australian National Audit Office—Administration of Grants Better Practice Guide and has put forward the view that the new 1998/99 Grant Procedures be adopted as the model procedures.

para.inline: (b) establish an information source for Aboriginal Councils and Island Councils and other interested parties, which detail the grants that are available and information about contact points within agencies. There should be Internet access to this information.

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives of the IDC do not support this part of the recommendation, which appears to be aimed at establishing a service point where clients can obtain information about grants from all agencies. In theory this sounds like a good idea however important issues to consider include possible reliability problems if the information is not constantly updated and the costs to provide the service.

para.inline: (c) require agencies to report back to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Queensland Public Accounts Committee on a biannual basis regarding implementation.

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives of the IDC support reporting biannually on the implementation of (a) only.
It is also noted that the report only covers about 25% of indigenous people in Queensland—those in DOGITS.

para.inline: At the regional level, Regional Grant Providers Forums should be created comprising representatives of all stakeholders. The role of these regional forums should mirror the role of the Grant Providers Forum, but address issues at the regional level.

speech.para: (See also comments for Recommendation 2).

Commonwealth representatives of the IDC do support the development of Regional Grant Providers Forums or their formalisation where they already exist, with the Queensland State Government sponsoring the establishment or formalisation of the regional forums.

ATSIC Queensland State Office has advised that a joint forum of ATSIC Project Officers and Community Service Officers was held in May 1997 and that a further joint forum is currently being arranged for approximately the same time this year.

More frequent Regional based forums will supplement this forum. A joint forum has already been initiated in Cairns with Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) as the main focus, given that the largest amount of funds provided to Councils comes through this program.

ATSIC Queensland State Office has also advised they intend to enter a formal arrangement by way of a joint letter signed off by the State Manager ATSIC and the Director of Office of Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander Affairs (OATSIA) to make the State forum a biannual event.

para.inline: The Grant Providers Forum should form a Training Working Group comprising representatives of all stakeholders. The tasks of the Training Working Group should include:
(a) the assessment of the training needs of Aboriginal Councils and Island Councils;
(b) the coordination of training provision to Aboriginal councils and Island Councils;

(c) seeking advice from the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Regional Development about the Remote Area Management Project with a view to assessing the usefulness of this initiative in providing a model for computer-based training to Aboriginal councils and Island Councils.
In performing its task the Training Working Group should take into account the training provided by Community Service Officers, internal auditors and others.

speech.para: Whilst the Commonwealth representatives of the IDC do not support the establishment of the Grant Provider Forum at Ministerial level, they do see great merit in establishing a structured training program for the boards and management of Aboriginal Councils and Torres Strait Island Councils.

There was concern also that training itself will not resolve issues associated with management instability within the Councils. There are many instances where problems have occurred in the grant administration area not as the result of lack of commitment but simply through a lack of basic administrative skills and knowledge of roles and responsibilities.

A number of Commonwealth agencies already have programs in place to provide support and training and it was considered that the co-ordination of assistance from agencies could best be handled at the regional level.

ATSIC will examine the possibility of whether Training Working Groups (TWG) be established as part of the proposed Regional Grant Providers Forums to formulate and coordinate training for the Councils at local level.

para.inline: Grant controllers should liaise with the Training Working Group to assist with identifying the training needs of Aboriginal Councils or Island Councils.

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives at the IDC discussed the differing roles played by grant controllers and no common outcome was reached.

ATSIC agrees that where a grant controller is appointed they should liaise with the Training Working Group to assist with identifying the training needs of Aboriginal Councils and Island Councils. The appointment of grant controllers is seen by both the Commission and the Queensland Government as an interim measure to enable community services to be maintained while further remedial action is implemented to restructure or strengthen community management.

para.inline: When agencies that provide funds to Aboriginal Councils or Island Councils undertake risk assessments of indigenous organisations they should take account of the results of risk assessments by other agencies and provide the results of their own risk assessment to other agencies via the Grant Providers Forum.

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives of the IDC indicated general support for this recommendation. It was also agreed that better results would be achieved if the exchange of information was made via the proposed Regional Grant Providers Forums rather than the overarching forum. The IDC agreed that prior to implementing the recommendation the relative legal and legislative requirements would need to be considered and clear advice provided to all agencies about the type of information that could be exchanged.

para.inline: The Grant Providers Forum address the issue of financial compliance, and maladministration of Council affairs, with a view to applying an interim step between full Council control of its affairs and the appointment of an administrator.

speech.para: Commonwealth representatives of the IDC supported ATSIC's belief that this recommendation was aimed at encouraging the Queensland Government to work through ATSIC appointed grant controllers rather than appointing administrators in the first instance.

Aboriginal Councils and Torres Strait Islander Councils are incorporated under Queensland legislation, therefore Commonwealth does not have power to appoint administrators. The IDC also understand that the Queensland Government does not currently have any powers to appoint grant controllers.
When funded organisations fail to comply with Commonwealth agency grant conditions there are a number of options available:

1. Agree on and implement a strategy to rectify breaches and prevent recurrence, this would also usually involve some tightening in report ing requirements (eg. Quarterly financial reports to monthly financial reports);
2. Appoint a Grant Controller; or
3. Implement defunding processes—this action is usually implemented when it becomes apparent that a funded body is incapable or unwilling to meet compliance standards.

Whilst the IDC did not support the recommendation to establish a Grant Providers Forum at Ministerial level there was agreement that the Regional Grant Providers Forum could liaise with the Queensland agencies to ascertain whether the use of Commonwealth grant controllers to assist with the administration of state funding is an alternative avenue.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the provisions of the Auditor-General Act 1997, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 31 of 1998-99—Performance audit—The management of performance information for specific purpose payments—The state of play .
—On behalf of Senator Carr, I move:

speech.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes:
(i) the unique and valuable contribution that the award winning internet service ABC Online has made to the multimedia services of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC),
(ii) that the Online gateway structure is now closely integrated with most ABC broadcasting services and is fully integrated with ABC news services,
(iii) that any attempts to privatise Online would have ramifications at every level of ABC services, and
