(iv) that ABC Online is integral to the way the ABC will operate and perform in the future;
(b) expresses concern at:
(i) proposals to privatise 49 per cent of ABC Online,
(ii) attempts to link future ABC funding to the privatisation of key services, and
(iii) government support for the privatisation of Online;
(c) condemns:
(i) the anti-ABC ideology of senior members of the Liberal Party of Australia,
(ii) the destabilising, anti-ABC stance of board member Mr Michael Kroger in pursuing a privatisation agenda to the detriment of the ABC, and

(iii) the active support given to Mr Kroger's privatisation agenda by the Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation (Mr McGauran), and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston); and
(d) calls on the Government to support the position of ABC Chair, Mr Donald McDonald, and ABC Managing Director, Mr Brian Johns, in their rejection of any sale of Online services.

The motion addresses four issues: firstly, the future structure of ABC Online; secondly, the apparent government intent to part-privatise ABC Online services; thirdly, the activities of a range of government and Liberal Party personnel actively orchestrating the move for privatisation; and finally, four, a call upon the government to reject any move to privatise ABC Online services. My contribution to this debate will touch upon the following five issues: firstly, the history and role of ABC Online; secondly, the future of media delivery in Australia; thirdly, why ABC Online is critical to the future of the ABC itself; fourthly, the position of government and the minister, as discussed in various public forums; and, finally, the position of the ABC expressed through its board and managing director, Mr Johns.

Turning firstly to the history and role of ABC Online, like everything, ABC Online had a relatively modest beginning. It commenced planning at the beginning of 1995, and operational work was delegated by the board in mid-1995. That decision resulted in the multimedia unit being instructed to build the ABC web site. Two staff were given that job and, on 14 August 1995, the ABC web site was launched.

Mr Johns has recently advised that the original grant to establish the ABC web site was in the order of only $750,000. Within 12 months the site had become one of the most popular in Australia. It had 2,500 pages of content, and 140,000 pages accesses per week. Some three years later, a successful service results: 24 full-time staff; extensive internal ABC ancillary support; and exceptional consumer demand, with 2,000 weekly page accesses as at August 1998.

ABC Online is not only successful in terms of growth in satisfying consumer demand but is also a critical success. ABC Online is one of the most visited web sites in Australia. ABC Online is consistently rated as one of the top five web sites in Australia. It has won, as we are all aware, numerous awards. In both 1996 and 1997 it was given the award for the best media web site in Australia. In 1997 it received four Australian teacher of media awards. In both 1997 and 1998 again it received specific awards for the production of CD-ROMs in a whole range of diverse areas—to mention a few: ingenious animated scientific adventure; Bananas in Pyjamas, winner of seven awards; and the Lab, the ABC science gateway. In January 1998, the Lab ABC science outline was listed as one of the top 40 web sites in the world by Australian Personal Computer magazine.

In summary, therefore, it is fair to conclude that ABC Online is a growing and productive area of the ABC. There is considerable consumer demand for its services. It has great critical recognition for delivery of those services around Australia. Also it is a critically important link in generating revenue for the ABC shops through the sale of products and services, and it has enormous capacity to increase that revenue in future years.

The future of media delivery in Australia is relatively easy to forecast. The Internet has developed, and is developing, as the third form of media delivery right around the world. First there was radio, second there was TV and now we have come into the age of the Internet. In five years time, the use of the Internet will be as simple as turning on a TV. So to restrict development of ABC Online, to sell it off, to sell it off in part or to privatise ABC Online is to say the ABC has no viable future.

talk.start.para: —What?
—Nonsense.
—Why don't you listen to the debate and you will find out why.
—We are. We cannot believe such nonsense.

—It is akin to pulling out the brain from a human body. We all know that you can keep a body alive through the provision of advanced medical services. People survive in comas and on machines for many years. They do not function as rational normal human beings in the way we have come to understand. Getting rid of the ABC Online service is akin to turning off that survival machine.

speech.para: TV, radio, Internet, computers and telephones are all in the process of convergence. The delivery system is in the process of being perfected. Look at the alliances developing all around the world—Microsoft, IBM, broadcasters, Telstra and big overseas telcos. The hardware, the software, the delivery methods and data reception are all in a process of convergence. The ABC Online Internet service is the first service with a true ability to provide text, data, sound, image and interactivity. From 2001 that capability will be available via TV. With the introduction of digital broadcasting, these traditional media services will all meld into one form. It is called convergence, and within two or three years it will be a fact of life in this country. The ABC board, if nothing else, was diligent in its planning for this new media world. The future of ABC Online is a future of convergence, traditional media services coming into one medium.

So the future of media delivery in Australia is fairly clear, but begs this question: why is the ABC Online service critical to the future of the ABC? That question was asked in the Senate estimates last week. ABC's Managing Director, Mr Brian Johns, addressed it in some detail. He described the ABC Online service as being at the heart and core of ABC activities. A press release of Thursday, 11 February states:

"ABC Online is at the heart of the ABC. It is a core asset. It is indivisible from radio and television, drawing resources and content from ABC program makers across all networks and around the country," Mr Johns said. ABC Online depends on input from the ABC's 800 journalists, the producers, presenters and program makers of each of the five radio networks, the television network and staff in 57 broadcast centres across the nation.

"The ABC has had to work smart to get where we are today. As a result we have one of the most popular and highly regarded Internet services in Australia. Despite lean funding we have been able to create a public asset of great value, by applying the information gathering resources of the national public broadcaster to the new communication medium.

"ABC Online is not a commercial service. Its roots are in the ABC Charter which requires us to serve a diverse range of different audience interests without reference to the ability to attract commercial revenue. It is a publicly funded national resource.
"Of course decisions about the future of ABC Online and any other policy matters affecting the development of digital broadcasting are continuing matters for the Board.
"The ABC has never shirked from the task of searching for external sources of funding revenue, provided these meet the requirements of the Charter.
"The success of ABC Enterprises, for instance, is the envy of many public broadcasters. Over the past five years it has increased its contribution to the ABC program budget six fold.
"ABC Online is the gateway to the future of digital communication for Australian audiences and ABC staff.

"The ABC's Online venture is our first foray into this new media world. We have been diligent and successful in developing our online expertise. ABC Online is the entry point for the organisation into a new media environment, and the entry point for millions of Australians to content on the Internet . . .
The managing director put it succinctly in estimates at page 143 early last week, when he said about ABC Online services:
It is not a limb to be cut off. It is not a limb to be amputated. It is right at the heart of the ABC.

I turn now to the position of the minister and the government. The subject was canvassed extensively at recent estimates hearings, as I said. There is no sense in reading out slabs or large extracts from Hansard . The government's position, as I understand it, is reasonably clear. It has four points: firstly, the government—or Minister Alston, as its representative—sees privatisation in whole or in part as whether you allow commercial involvement without compromising charter obligations and standards set for the ABC generally; secondly, the ABC should seriously consider all options that might benefit from synergies that derive from commercial operators; thirdly, convergence leads to commercial opportunity and new marketing opportunities—the ABC suffers from lack of expertise in this area; and, fourthly, future revenue streams or significant additional funding arrangements are linked inextricably with new commercial opportunities.

Minister Alston refuses to comment on the views of Mr Johns or the board. It appears to be fairly Alice in Wonderland stuff. For example, if we sell 33 per cent or 49 per cent of Telstra, we call it part privatisation. If we sell the ABC or 49 per cent of ABC Online for $250 million to retire debt, as is suggested, the minister says it is not privatisation, not a substantial sale of an asset, but the selling off of a portion or entering into a joint venture.

On the contrary, in respect of ABC Online services, Mr Johns said it is an integral part of the ABC's future. It goes to the core of the ABC. It is a core asset, he said. It is central to its very digital future. Minister Alston said of ABC Online services that it is simply another ABC delivery platform, that it is not integral to the ABC, that the charter obligations are integral to the ABC and that the fulfilment of charter obligations can be done through commercial means. So the minister is being quite straightforward here. The ABC, whether by design, planning or accident, for relatively low cost has created something of real value, something of real commercial appeal and something attracting and retaining significant markets. Mr Kroger understood that as a merchant banker.

The value derives from a number of aspects of ABC Online services—firstly, additional revenue from online services, presumably the huge cashflows that are generated, and, secondly, access to other ABC markets because of digital conversion and delivery system convergence. For example, ABC radio has 25 per cent to 40 per cent of the market in every state and territory of Australia. It has strong brand names in Triple J, Radio Classic FM, various regional stations and news radio. The TV has a strong brand name in terms of the national network. The third area of value is the physical assets of the ABC, which are declining. Buildings are losing value and the technology is making a lot of equipment very cheap to replace. As a consequence, operational costs will become lower over time for a range of reasons.

So commercial access, commercial control and commercial ownership in whole or in part will be like owning a printing press at the Treasury. Mr Kroger knows that. Minister Alston knows that. Mr Johns, the Managing Director of the ABC, knows that. Hence this whole sorry episode. Of course, members of the public also know that. If we look at the letters to the editor section of, I think, today's Australian, we will see a whole heap of letters under the heading, `Hands off! It's our ABC, Mr Kroger'. Mr Walter Bass, Founding President of the Friends of the ABC, Turramurra, New South Wales, says:
If Michael Kroger's extraordinary letter . . . reflects the views of the Government he represents in a de facto capacity, the ABC is indeed, as he says, condemned to a bleak future.

From its inception, it was intended that the national broadcaster should provide independent, government-funded radio—and later television—providing world-class entertainment and information. Mr Kroger ignores the fact that it was never the intention nor, as many polls have demonstrated over the years, is it the wish of the public, that the ABC "should seriously compete with the commercials," as Mr Kroger implies.

Seen in that light all Mr Kroger's talk of cyberspace, digitalisation and "financial resource bases" becomes irrelevant. It is clearly the duty of the Government to adequately finance the ABC and to preserve its independence. Perhaps when Mr Kroger has digested this fact, he might pass it on to his colleagues in Canberra.
Similarly, a Mr Peter Symons from Brunswick East in Victoria said:

Mr Kroger doesn't seem to understand the inherent danger to the ABC's editorial independence if any part of it is privatised. To have a member of the ABC board ignorant of these basic tenets of our public broadcaster is deeply worrying.

There is a whole range of other letters that follow the same theme. In a nutshell, the government and the minister know and say the following: digital conversion and media convergence create huge value in ABC Online services. That value comes in the form of huge surplus cash flows generated from advertising revenue and from gatekeeper to other ABC services and markets. This is a commercial opportunity and should be exploited by partial sale. The stalking horse here is a merchant banker from Victoria, presumably acting on behalf of his own interests or a range of commercial interests.

The position of the ALP, the position of the opposition, is very simple in this matter. We will not be in it. We will not participate in the flogging off of any part of ABC Online. Whether it be 10 per cent, 25 per cent, 35 per cent or the lot, we will retain it in public hands. The value will remain in the hands of the government on behalf of taxpayers. An additional value through commercial services is a matter properly for resolution by the board, not merchant bankers in Victoria.

On a final note, we are satisfied that the ABC charter properly allows ABC Online services to remain in public hands and not be partly privatised or fully privatised in due course. In particular, we refer the Senate to section 6(1)(a)(i) and section 6(2)(a)(iii). Section 6(1)(a) says the functions of the corporation are:

. . . to provide within Australia innovative and comprehensive broadcasting services of a high standard as part of the Australian broadcasting system consisting of national, commercial and community sectors and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, to provide—
(i) broadcasting programs that contribute to a sense of national identity and inform and entertain, and reflect the cultural diversity of, the Australian community . . .

The key phrases in that ABC charter are `innovative and comprehensive broadcasting services' and `the responsibility of the corporation as the provider of an independent national broadcasting service'. There is a certain logical position that derives from the inclusion of those provisions in the charter.

If the ABC Online service is a gateway after digital conversion and media convergence, it is absolutely necessary that it remain in public hands. If ABC Online services are integral and critical to the entire future of the ABC, it should remain in public hands. It strikes me that, when one looks at those particular phrases in the ABC charter, it is absolutely counter to the intent of the charter, as decided by parliament, for the ABC Online services when it becomes a gatekeeper—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We are considering Senator Carr's general business notice of motion on the ABC's Online Internet service and I sat and listened with interest to some of the comments of Senator Bishop. I recall, with some amusement actually, Senator Carr's involvement in this whole area some five years ago when we had an inquiry into the ABC, and I will be referring to that in a few minutes. What we have here again is an attempt by the opposition to portray this government as anti-ABC. Nothing could be further from the truth.
—You have cut the ABC's funding.

—I will get to that point in a minute, Senator Bishop, if you just give me a second. I have observed public broadcasting in countries like the United States, and Australia is way ahead. We have a terrific public broadcasting system. Along with the United Kingdom with the BBC, we have a world-class service of a very high quality.

speech.para: It always seems to disturb members on the other side when we want to try to bring some sort of efficiency measures or the natural laws of economics into some of these operations. I remind the Senate that we contribute almost half a billion dollars of taxpayer funds into the ABC, and the ABC has developed, in response to that, a very comprehensive range of television and radio programs and now Internet services, which is the subject of this motion. So I think we have a lot to be proud of. Senator Bishop seems to be disturbed by the fact that, in our budget savings program in 1996, we reduced the revenue of the ABC. It was not by too much, but we did reduce it.

talk.start.para: —Not by too much?
—Senator Bourne, I would be amazed if a commercial station like Channel 9—
—Channel 9!

—or Channel 7 or Channel 10 would be disturbed if their revenues varied by a few per cent. That is the commercial world, and particularly the commercial world in this area of media. The ABC have been cocooned for decades by a set budget that just keeps expanding and expanding and expanding. When we came into government, we put into place quite a number of efficiency operations right across the whole span of government. It was not just the ABC involved; it was the whole span of government. In that way, we closed off the Beazley black hole of $10 billion and got the economy back on the right track, and that is why we enjoy the prosperity we do today. We were not taking services away from the ABC; we were actually making them more efficient and they had to respond in that sort of way. If they chose to cut programs, that was the decision of their board. There are many other areas they could have cut if they had chosen to do so, but they did not.

speech.para: We have a situation with this Online service where people like Senator Carr get very upset if there is a proposal—and let me say that it is just a proposal by one board member—that they privatise part of this operation. Perhaps we might get involved in some joint operation with other players in the whole Internet industry. Wouldn't that be a terrible thing to have commercial alliances with other operations that are possibly more efficient!

talk.start.para: —With Channel 9 perhaps. Channel 9 is very efficient.

—And that have better technology! And that have better programming! These sorts of alliances in the commercial world, Senator Bourne, happen all the time. The whole industry grows and becomes more powerful because of those sorts of alliances.
—Read the charter, John.

—We had Senator Bishop using all these medical analogies. I am trying to give you the medical analogy that what we are proposing here is a transfusion—actually giving something that can be developed. Senator Bishop talked about this whole system being the heart of the ABC. He talked about cutting off limbs. It was a very depressing medical analogy, but I would like to turn that around and say that, as we have discovered with operations like Telstra and as even the last Labor government discovered with operations like the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas, when you privatise, you actually get a more efficient operation and a more profitable operation.
—Rubbish!

—Oh? The Commonwealth Bank is not profitable? I assume you are speaking later in this debate, Senator Bourne. You will have plenty of time to have your say. There is none so deaf as those who don't listen. If you listen, you might learn something in this debate.
—Come on! Not from you!

—I would be humble enough to say you might, so let us push on. The whole thing about what has been proposed so far is that the board has the right to make a decision to do this if it wants to. We have an independent charter for the ABC. The ABC is not run by the minister. It is actually run by an independent board. If that board decides it wants to increase its revenue in certain ways—provided they are within the charter—it can certainly do so. On a number of occasions in the past, it did so under the Labor Party. I am sure Senator Carr will remember this, and I am thinking back to 1993—or was it 1994, Senator Carr?—and the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations. Do you remember that?
—That rort that Alston organised.
—I am glad you remembered, Senator Carr.
—Yes, I do. That scam.

—You will recall, Senator Carr, that the ABC was under the ill-fated direction of David Hill at that time, and you remember him. He crashed and burned when he ran for the seat of Hughes recently against the redoubtable Danna Vale. He did not do particularly well. You will recall, Senator Carr, when we were on that inquiry that it was revealed that he had taken the ABC in a number of very ill-fated commercial directions at that time.
—Kroger wants to do it again.

—Senator Carr, if I recall, you were arguing at the time that this was a matter for the ABC and you said, `It wasn't a matter for us in government to be interfering in. We shouldn't be having inquiries into it.' As a matter of fact, if I remember correctly, you spent most of the inquiry talking to Senator Forshaw, talking and laughing fairly loudly through a great part of it. That is when you were not defaming Senator Alston. You really got your fingers burnt on that. But I will not go into that rather delicate matter.

speech.para: Let us go into some of the things that were done by David Hill as managing director, with the agreement of his board at that time and under the independence of the ABC—the sorts of things that they did to raise additional funds for the ABC. Senator Bourne, the ABC must have felt that, under the previous Labor government, they did not have enough money because they kept going out and trying to raise money in various commercial ways.

talk.start.para: —That is true.

—Let us have a look at what they did. They set up ATI—we all remember that. That was their ill-fated Asia TV service, which was set up in such a way that it was supposed to break even. But it was such an ill-conceived concept and operated so poorly that that never happened. It eventually went broke and was wound up.

speech.para: Then there was the infamous infotainment saga. I am sure that Senator Carr remembers that. That little scam was eventually wound up after it was exposed—with rather dubious commercial connections, the way it was all done—by an expose program on Channel 9. So that was the end of that one.

talk.start.para: —Now you want to sell the ABC to Packer.
—We are just going through the disastrous record of commercialisation with the ABC under your government, Senator Carr.

speech.para: Let us get to the third one, which was pay TV. The government were going to form an alliance between the ABC and Fairfax press. That started under way, but Fairfax press must have realised what they were dealing with commercially and, quite sensibly, they got out of the deal. So that one did not go anywhere as well. That was a great pity, because the public broadcaster should have moved into pay TV. But, under the ill-conceived policies of the previous government and the way in which the ABC was operated by their managing director, they did not get the chance.

Then there was one other: the news service which was supposed to be the Reuters of Australia and was going to compete with AAP. But they could not get enough takers for that news service so that eventually folded. That inquiry really called the ABC to book at that time. Within six months of the end of that inquiry, the managing director, David Hill, and the top of the ABC hierarchy had all departed. But we had Senator Carr and other members of the government at the time defending the ABC's fierce independence and right to do this sort of thing under their charter.

In contrast, it is interesting to go to the ALP election policy of last year, which said that they would direct how the ABC should spend its money. They seem to have reversed their policy last year because Senator Carr's motion now criticises the government, saying that it is up to the ABC and its board of management. What a confused party! With the ALP being in such a policy free zone, I suppose we just get these flip-flops from one side to the other. Perhaps we should read Mark Latham's or Lindsay Tanner's books; we might get some guidance on where the ALP is going in this area.

Let us get back to the nub of what Senator Carr's motion is suggesting. Here we are occupying the time of the Senate—for about an hour and a half, I assume—on a matter that is subject to the view of one board member of the ABC. One board member has made a suggestion—shock, horror!—and that suggestion is to bring some privatisation, up to a certain percentage, into the Online service. That is a suggestion of a member of the board. Why on earth is it occupying the time of this parliament? This is quite a silly motion. Of all the issues facing Australia, why are we debating this?

I went to a drug crisis summit in Newcastle last night, and we had 400 people turn up. A lot of them were parents of children who died and children who were on drugs. If you want an issue, boy, is that an issue. Then look by contrast at what we are considering: the comment of one board member from the ABC.

Senator Carr, if you look at international practice you will realise that what is being suggested by Mr Kroger—indeed, what was attempted by your last government with four ill-fated attempts which were badly managed by the former managing director—is moving in the direction of the ABC raising funds in legitimate ways within its own charter and that it actually fixes the problem that Senator Bourne has raised. She has been grumbling and complaining all through my contribution here today. Her basic point is that the ABC does not get enough funding. Well, if that is your view, Senator Bourne, you should support these sorts of arrangements, because the ABC will get more funding under them.
Senator Bourne interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yet you seem to object to that. You seem to have the view that government is an endless pit of money and all we need to do is just keep expanding the budget of the ABC.
—What do you do with taxes, for goodness sake?

—What do we do with taxes? We spend it on a very wide range of services, all that are demanding more and more. Senator Bourne, most of the increase goes into the health and welfare areas which are not very good at self-funding. What about activities that can raise funding; what about a high quality broadcaster like the ABC which has the capacity—through the selling of programs through commercial alliances such as the Online service—to actually raise additional funds and fund the organisation in the way that they want. This motion by Senator Carr is a total nonsense. It is a waste of the Senate's time. Senator Carr, I would invite you to get real and to get on with some real issues.

—I don't know where to start. Yes, I do know where to start. I am going to start with a motion for the suspension of standing orders that was moved by Senator Alston. We all know Senator Alston. Senator Alston is currently the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. On 30 June 1994 he moved a motion for the suspension of standing orders because there was a matter he thought was so important that it should take up the time of the Senate. And it was a very important motion. I supported him on this. The motion was:

speech.para: . . . that the Senate deplores the blatant politicisation of the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in flagrant disregard of its statutory obligations.

That was an extremely important motion. I supported him. The fact was that the ALP was putting ALP people on the board. The fact was that they had not adequately explained why they were doing that. The Liberal Party at the time, through Senator Alston and through other senators, was totally outraged that this was happening. They, of course, would never do such a thing—they would have put people on the board who could demonstrate that they had no close connections with the Liberal Party and that they were being put on the board purely because they were worth having on that board.
Let me tell you how Senator Alston finished that speech. It was a very good, strong finish. It is probably right as we speak today. He said:
I say in conclusion—
this is from the Senate Hansard of 30 June 1994—

that what we have here is a classic stacked deck of which a Mississippi gambler would be very proud. It is yet another example of Mr Keating's `all spoils to the victor' approach to politics. It has, I think, a serious capacity to undermine the integrity and reputation of an esteemed Australian institution.

That was what he was saying on 30 June 1994. On 27 June, just before that, he made a few other very pertinent points. They were that the appointment of people who had a very obvious connection with one side of politics to a board such as the ABC board was dangerous because it raised the more serious concern about the imminent appointments to the board of the ABC. Senator Alston stated:
The board of the ABC, when it started out under another name, was one that prided itself on its independence. Indeed, as Professor Armstrong, the chairman of the ABC—
on 27 June 1994—
says in his commentary on communications law and policy in Australia:
On the ABC's inaugural broadcast, the Prime Minister, Mr Joe Lyons, declared that the government's purpose was to appoint able and impartial trustees for an important national service.
Senator Alston goes on to say:

. . . it is absolutely critical that the ABC is not compromised in its work and that it does have a genuine and impartial board . . . Otherwise we end up with a stacked deck . . . to have people there who will not act in the best interests of the taxpayer but simply in the best interests of the ALP . . .

In this case it was the ALP. Let me suggest that in the current case it seems to be the Liberal Party. I don't think anybody can deny that Mr Kroger has very, very strong links with the Liberal Party, but his friendships go further, into commercial broadcasting.

Mr Kroger has been suggesting several things. One of the things Mr Kroger has been suggesting is that the ABC look at privatising just under half of ABC Online. We heard from Mr Kroger. He was writing to the newspapers saying that the ABC has to stop being reliant on government handouts. I don't think Mr Kroger quite understands what the ABC is based on. I don't think he quite understands that it is supposed to be completely impartial, that it cannot have advertising on it because, once it has advertising on it, it can't be completely impartial. The quality and the type of broadcasting we have in Australia in all its forms depends on its source of funding. So it is really important that we have a national broadcaster.

I agree with Senator Tierney when he says that we have a terrific public broadcasting service in this country—but we won't for long unless we fund it properly. We fund it from the public purse. At the moment each of us is paying, I think, less than 6c a day. It is not 8c a day. I am happy to pay 8c a day, I am happy to pay 10c a day, I am happy to pay a $1 a day—but then, I am a high income earner. If you look at the latest survey about what people think of the ABC you will find that 86 per cent of the respondents to that Newspoll survey said that they thought ABC television can be rated as good, compared to commercial television, which 44 per cent rated as good.

So twice as many Australians—86 per cent—think that ABC television can be rated as good compared with the number who rate commercial television as good. That is almost exactly the same result we keep getting in these surveys. It is going to have to go down sooner or later once the funding downfall, the dreadful slashing in funding, that has happened under this government really starts kicking in. At the moment 86 per cent of Australians still believe that ABC TV is really good, whereas only 44 per cent of Australians think the same about commercial TV.

So Australians do believe that the ABC is something they want to maintain. In a survey two years ago they said that it was the greatest force for good in this community. It beat the police, the judiciary, politicians and journalists into the ground. It beat everybody. The ABC was seen by more than 85 per cent—I think it was 85 per cent—of respondents as being the greatest force for good in this country. `Oh, well let's get rid of it. Let's stop it being what it is and what it is seen to be.' Is that what this government wants to do? Is that why it is slashing all these funds? Is that what is happening here? I wish somebody would tell me it isn't, because I cannot believe that is not the case.

ABC Online is an integral part of the ABC's broadcast role. To sell it off would be like selling off the TV part, or the radio part. It is one way that the ABC achieves its charter obligations—unless you want to change the charter, nothing much is happening—to reach as many Australians with as much information as possible. Just as the ABC had a responsibility to make use of TV to reach Australians when that medium reached Australia, so it must use digital formats like the Online service. This is a really popular and valuable service. That is obviously why Mr Kroger thinks it should be got rid of. He thinks there will be a one-off injection and then the government will not have to pay that money.

The government seems to think that income from tax revenue belongs to it, that it is its money, that it belongs to every member of the cabinet, that it belongs to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to do what they like with. It doesn't. It belongs to all Australians. It belongs to me, it belongs to you—it belongs to you, Madam Acting Deputy President. It belongs to everybody in this chamber. Most importantly, it belongs to every Australian outside this chamber, outside this Parliament House. That is who the ABC belongs to.

The ABC is not the plaything of this government. It is not the plaything of Mr Kroger. It is not the plaything of this minister. The ABC belongs to every Australian, and the ABC ought to be able to be used by every Australian. It ought to be able to be used in an impartial fashion. It ought to not have advertising on it, no matter what. It ought to be something that is funded so that it cannot be influenced by outside influences, such as corporations which might advertise on the ABC, ABC Online or anywhere on the ABC.

ABC Online is the digital precursor of more things to come in the ABC in Australia. The expertise that has been developed now in ABC Online will be used in digital television. It will be used in digital radio. It will be used in the convergence of other technologies that are coming. We all know they are coming. The minister keeps telling us that these things are about to hit us. That is where the technology is going to train people. The use of that technology will train people within the ABC to be able to switch over to digital TV, to be able to switch over to digital radio. ABC Online is an integral part of the ABC as it stands at the moment.

Mr Kroger tells us that the sale of ABC Online will give the ABC funds to do its job and meet its charter obligations. It is the government's responsibility to fund the ABC adequately to do its job under the charter. It is not the ABC's job to sell off bits, to cobble together some inadequate service for all Australians. Just as the government of the day—the Menzies government—enthusiastically funded the ABC to go into television and to go into Radio Australia—and I will say a bit about that later—it should fund the ABC adequately to meet the digital age.

Broadcasting in Australia has depended on the ABC for innovative programming, training and development of services. The reason the ABC has done these things is that its funding base is different from the commercial sector. Its different funding source and charter have driven the ABC to provide programming which is different from the commercial channels. That is very important. We all remember Mr Bob Mansfield and we remember Mr Mansfield's report on the ABC. I am reasonably certain that the minister expected it to come out differently from what it did.

Mr Mansfield believed, and I am sure still believes, that you would need $500 million to run a national broadcasting service. Keep in mind that is a national television and a national radio broadcasting service, with several radio networks—$500 million. That is not what this government is giving the ABC to run its service. What this government is giving the ABC according to the figure in the last budget was $486 million and that included the orchestras. I think it was $467 million without the orchestras. That is spectacularly down from what it needs. Obviously the strain is beginning to show.

Despite that, ABC Online is one of the best online services in Australia. It is one of the most popular online services in Australia. It is not just that: the funding for the ABC has to include in the future the change to the digital era of television and the digital era of radio, and we do not even know where that is going yet. Goodness knows where the funding for that is coming from, because as far as the funding for digital television is concerned the government has promised $20.7 million. They will get that. They need at least $184 million. So they will get $20.7 million.

The estimates given by the Arthur Andersen report into the digitisation strategy of the ABC are that it will take about $184 million for the ABC to be able to fully digitise. That is quite small when you consider that they will have to digitise an entire national rural and urban network of television. It compares extremely favourably when you compare it with what the commercial television networks believe they would need, which was somewhere in the vicinity of between $500 and $700 million—that is off the top of my head, so I am not sure—between the three of them to do the same thing only with their urban networks.

The Arthur Andersen report was completely independent—utterly independent. I do not see the government getting independent reports into what everybody else thinks they are going to need for digitisation, but that bill went through anyway. Still, they got an independent report into what the ABC would need, and the independent report agreed with what the ABC had estimated in the first place, which I believe was $184 million. Where is the ABC going to get the $184 million? They will not get it from selling ABC Online, and they are not going to get it from the government at this rate either. The government have promised $20.7 million. They have promised to underwrite another $24 million, and the minister says, `Don't worry, of course we will fund the ABC to go to digital television.'

Then I see a quote from the minister after Mr Kroger's suggestion was made public which says that this may be a very good way for the ABC to fund going to digital. Excuse me, I believe the minister said that the government would fund the ABC going to digital. I think that is the only reasonable way to fund going to digital. The government has, after all, given the commercial free-to-air networks free spectrum in the digital spectrum for a number of years because they believe it will cost them a lot of money to go to digital, and it will not cost them as much as it costs the ABC. If the government is willing to give the commercial networks a foot-up in relation to exclusive digital spectrum for a number of years because of the costs, they really ought to be looking after their own duties—and it is a duty on their part—to fund the ABC properly to go into digital television.

I would like to make one last point about ABC funding. It is one of my favourite points: the funding of Radio Australia, which is of course part of the ABC. If you look at the ABC Online service, you will find that they have Radio Australia as part of that service. You can find what has been on Radio Australia recently. You can find transcripts of some of the articles, and you can find a lot of other information.

The problem with Radio Australia is that if you live, work or are in most of Asia, and particularly most of South-East Asia, you will not be able to hear it on short-wave radio. The reason for that is that the state-of-the-art transmitter, which is located in Darwin at Cox Peninsula, has been turned off by the ABC. It has been turned off by the ABC because the government told them to do that. The government is very proud of the fact they told them to do that because they have saved $1.4 million year. For that saving of $1.4 million a year what they have achieved is that they have got off side a huge number of ordinary citizens in South-East Asia.

And what about the heads of state that wrote and said, `Would you please not turn off the Radio Australia short-wave service'? They cannot be particularly pleased that it was, in fact, turned off. I had a prominent Cambodian in my office only a couple of weeks ago and, after discussing matters that were going on in Cambodia, he said, `I have to ask you one more thing: is it at all possible for you to influence the government to turn back on the Radio Australia short-wave service? We need it so much in Cambodia.' They do need it in Cambodia. They need it in Vietnam. They need it in Indonesia. They need it in all those countries of Asia, and particularly South-East Asia, that are currently having problems. They are sorting out their problems, but they are currently having problems.

That Radio Australia short-wave transmission is desperately needed by the people of South-East Asia. It is desperately needed by Australians travelling in South-East Asia. It is one of the most unbiased and respected services in the world. At the moment you can get it if you have a satellite dish and satellite receiver. It is going out on satellite into Asia, but it is not going out in the form of broadcast which is affordable to pretty well all South-East Asians, in the form of broadcast which is really difficult to block and in the form of broadcast which is widely listened to around South-East Asia not only by the ordinary South-East Asians on the ground but also by Australian tourists, by Australian business people, by Australians travelling in South-East Asia. It is an absolute disgrace that this government has turned that off and has left that off. It is a disgrace that they are not listening to the people or even to the governments of South-East Asia who would like that service turned back on.

In conclusion, it would be a huge backward step for the ABC to sell any part of its basic service to all Australians. Let us just remember: all Australians own the ABC—not this government, not this minister and not even the board. It would be a dreadful backward step for any part of the ABC, including ABC Online, to be sold off, to be commercialised, to be beholden on advertising from someone who can then take away that advertising if they do not like what is going on at the ABC.

It would be a dreadful shame if any Australian government believed that they did not have to fund a public broadcasting service. It is called a public broadcasting service because it is a public broadcasting service, because it does not depend on any one commercial interest in order to be on the air. That means it can be innovative. That means it can be ahead of its time. That means it can take risks. And those risks have led to so many things that Australians value. Its unbiased nature has led to so many things that Australians value. Any diminution of that is a dimin ution of the Australian lifestyle, and I would fight it to the end.

talk.start.para: —I rise to make a brief contribution to this afternoon's debate on general business notice of motion No. 119 standing in the name of Senator Carr. In doing so I would like to note that the observations that are made in the motion noting the unique and valuable contribution that the award winning Internet service ABC Online has made to the multimedia services of the ABC and that the online gateway structure is closely integrated with most ABC broadcasting services and fully integrated with ABC news services are, in fact, statements with which I am happy to agree.

speech.para: ABC Online, established in 1995 to initiate the ABC's involvement with multimedia, is an excellent valuable resource for all Australians and, obviously, for those much further afield. It is the network within the ABC that coordinates all ABC online activities and web sites as well as multimedia projects. It is an award winning Internet service. But, as such, it and any other aspect of the ABC should not for some bizarre reason be absolutely immune from any discussion of progress or change within that community of communications and information technology.

It seems to me curious that the opposition is not even prepared to look at, to consider, issues around the idea floated because that would somehow be breaking new ground. It would somehow be an idea which they would totally reject. I find it ironic in the extreme that they would attack Michael Kroger—or anyone else, for that matter—for floating ideas about the operations of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. It is ironic that people who were always so protective of the capacity of the ABC to float ideas from outside the mainstream would be critical of someone for doing exactly that, critical of somebody for being independent and free-thinking. Apparently the only way you get to make a statement in this country anymore is if you agree with the ALP.

I was fortunate enough to be in estimates last week when this issue was discussed, and I think the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts said some very useful things that regard, which I would like to refer to today. It is important to the ABC and it is important to public broadcasting in this nation that there is not just a knee-jerk response to the issues that we are discussing today and that the ABC itself, I guess, does not get caught up in what the minister described as `political crossfire' about whether this amounts to privatisation or whether it amounts to commercial encroachment.

Senator Bourne referred simply to advertising in her speech in relation to matters of commercialisation, but it is important to note that we are talking about more than one source of possible revenue in that regard. It could be advertising but, more than that, it could be subscription or the sale of products. You can have one, any or none of those. But it is not the case that you should exclude consideration of the options, and that is what the opposition is suggesting today.

I am highly diverted by the fact that the mover of the motion proposes that we give support to the ABC chair, Mr Donald McDonald. He is a person who does an excellent job in that capacity but—at any turn, at any moment, no matter what he says or what he does—he is usually attacked and criticised by those opposite for somehow being tainted in that environment. But today, apparently, it is okay to support Mr McDonald. I, for one, am a very strong supporter of Mr McDonald and am happy to see him in that responsible position.

It seems to me that what we should be talking about today is how ABC Online can look to its future and look at opportunities for innovation and change. A good online service, a good web site and any of its services do not need to be 100 per cent government owned to make it effective. What it needs to be is informative, expeditious and easily accessible. Look at how many other web sites—commercial and otherwise—have been pioneers of the information age. Dare I make reference to the classic case of the Drudge report in the United States, which breaks news reports of enormous international proportions and is operated by only one man? Not that I would ever make a comparison between that and ABC Online, I hasten to add.

Nobody disagrees with the importance of a vibrant online community. In fact, as far as this government is concerned, this is an absolutely integral part of our move into the next century. An Online Australia Day is going to provide a national focus for exactly that. In the launch of Online Australia 1999, we have a national focus on the information economy. I am sure that those interested will know that ABC Online will play a very important part in that area.

Australia is already a globally recognised leader in the use of new technologies, including the Internet, e-commerce, IT, the development of computer software and hardware and all sorts of other online applications. These are transforming the daily lives of Australians. But to try to say, as the opposition has this afternoon that, as a knee-jerk reaction or automatic response to an unusually heightened level of paranoia, we should not even consider or discuss some of the suggestions which are around on this issue is extraordinarily narrow-minded and extraordinarily focused on their own interests.

The minister put the point particularly well in estimates last week, when he said that it was important `to look at whether there are ways in which they'—meaning the ABC—`can benefit from the synergies that derive from involvement with commercial operators'. Unless looking at synergies is now a crime under the laws created by the opposition is this regard, I think that is a very valuable suggestion to make. People who often regard each other as competitors are constantly, I believe, being involved in things like joint ventures—sometimes quite outside their traditional areas of activity—because, as the minister has said, there is `mutual benefit in understanding and getting new perspectives on the way in which business is done'. If members of the ABC board, or anyone else for that matter, see fit to make suggestions in that regard, Mr Acting Deputy President, I and the government, I think, see no reason why those issues cannot be explored in a mature, sensible debate. But it would seem that those opposite would disagree.

The contribution of ABC Online to the health of the ABC's digital services is also well recorded in some of the statements of Mr Brian Johns at estimates last week. ABC Online uses `specialist program makers' providing material online from over `800 journalists'. That is a very important part of access, particularly for rural and regional Australia, right through Australia's radio networks. The ABC uses the full weight of the corporation to back that up, to maximise results and to capitalise on them, as Mr Johns as said. Nobody disagrees with the contribution that ABC Online can make to the provision of news and information. The issue is, apparently, whether it needs to be government owned. Ultimately, of course, that is a matter for the board and a matter which the board will consider, I am sure, in the due course of events.

The whole debate should not be about one side or the other of politics. It should be about the provision of quality services. In terms of discussion of ideas for the future, there has only been the suggestion of a small element of commercialisation in this regard. The issue is about the future; it is about considering the best operation of ABC Online within the whole ABC corporation and the best contribution that it can make to the sorts of things that Senator Bourne was talking about. I think she used the phrase `cobbled together'. I do not know whether she meant that people in Australia find that the ABC is cobbled together, but I would absolutely reject that. The government supports a strong and independent ABC; it always has and it always will. In discussing the future of parts of the ABC, like ABC Online, the government, at least, is prepared to be open minded and to consider all the options available.

talk.start.para: —The motion that I moved today calls on the government to support the position of the ABC chair, Mr Donald McDonald, and the ABC managing director, Mr Brian Johns, in their rejection of any sale of the Online services. Given that the Prime Minister's friend, Mr McDonald, has made his strong position clear on this, I think it is only appropriate that this Senate agree with him on this matter which is at the heart of the future direction of the ABC.

speech.para: It is clear from the debate we have had today that it is left once again to the opposition to come to the defence of the ABC. It is the Labor Party that seeks to defend the organisation from a government which is intent upon undermining its pillars of independence and intent upon dismantling its key functions. The move to privatise the ABC's Internet vehicle, Online, is just one of a series of attacks on the viability of the organisation. This is an organisation that is doing very well despite the persistent financial and rhetorical attacks launched upon it by this government. It follows constant attacks upon the ABC and its integrity. It follows severe budget cutbacks, programming cutbacks, attacks upon Australian content and Radio Australia cutbacks—the list goes on—all of which stem directly from the government's policy of removing hundreds of millions of dollars from the budget of the ABC.

This motion is as much about the activities of a Liberal stalwart and the ABC board member Mr Michael Kroger as it is about protecting ABC Online itself. We should all remember just who this Michael Kroger is. He has a record of attacking the ABC for what he perceives to be its biased political coverage. By that he means that it does not agree with the Liberal Party's point of view in any election campaign. Senator Abetz's very good understanding of an even-handed approach to broadcasting is that both the National Party and the Liberal Party get a fair cut of the action to the exclusion of all others.

We saw, for instance, in regard to Mr Kroger's complaints about the ABC during the election campaign that the Age reported on 20 September 1998 that the ABC received 22 written complaints over its election coverage. One-third of those 22 complaints came from the Liberal Party director, Mr Lynton Crosby. At least another three had been made by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, who is the failed manager of the Liberal Party's election campaign in Victoria.

It is the same Mr Kroger who promised and failed to deliver the Age newspaper to Mr Packer. He spearheaded the PBL's failed campaign to convince the government to change its cross-media laws to allow Mr Packer to take over the Fairfax Holdings. It is the same Mr Kroger who also failed in his work that he did for News Ltd. He was at least even-handed in that regard. Remember when he sought to reverse the decision to give free spectrum to the commercial networks for digital television? It is the same Mr Kroger who was unsuccessful in his lobbying on behalf of the National Bank for the government to relax its four pillars policy to enable the NBA to merge with the ANZ.

talk.start.para: —So far.

—That may well be the case, Senator, that it is so far. But up to this point it is a failed lobbying effort. It is the same Mr Kroger who has acted as the chief spin doctor for the Solomon Lew family in their unsuccessful takeover of Country Road. He was the chief lobbyist for Solomon Lew's attempt to keep his Reserve Bank board seat. Importantly, his merchant bank, J.T. Campbell and Co., despite its enormously weak financial record, makes most of its money out of these various predatory moves against various other entities directly tied with lobbying government.

speech.para: It is well known that J.T. Campbell lacks the financial resources to pitch for the mega deals, so therefore he concentrates on these niche arrangements. Mr Kroger's only real big money-spinner seems to be from his role as the deputy chair of Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting. It is a role that many in Melbourne are only too happy to talk to the press about because it has upset them so much, particularly given Mr Kroger's role as a spokesperson in Rinehart's bitter legal battles with her father's ex-wife, Rose Porteous.

In short, Mr Kroger's business and lobbyist activities to date have been unsuccessful, and at best one could say they have been entirely dependent upon what is perceived by some as his links to government. In fact, what you see from this is a record of failure, of waning political influence within the halls of power within the Liberal Party. Mr Kroger strongly advertises what he sees as his success fees. This is why he is doing so badly financially, because his business deals hinge so strongly on receipt of success fees, which he very rarely obtains. His well-known political affiliations and close personal contacts and friendships with Mr Costello and Senator Alston have been a real negative for him and, I suspect, for them. One has to admire Mr Kroger for his persistence and his determination to battle on.

Now his latest business venture is the sale of ABC Online. One has to speculate that perhaps in the future Mr Kroger might resign from the ABC board and set himself up as a go-between for the Packer organisation and the government, given the Packer organisation is so intent on establishing itself in this Internet arena of business activity. However, we have to acknowledge the issue of Mr Kroger's influence on the Liberal Party itself. It raises real questions as to the extent to which he is able to influence anything at all.

We saw the great adventure he had with the Liberal Party preselections in Victoria just last year with Senator Synon and with the way in which Jeff Kennett comprehensively did him over. Even Jeff Kennett, who has made so many comments about other senators here, has made it very clear what he thinks about Senator Synon and her chief patron—

talk.start.para: —Has he ever said anything about Eric?

—He probably would not know him at all. Jeff Kennett understands Mr Kroger's waning influence in the Liberal Party and his attempt to promote Mr Costello, naturally enough, against the interests of so many. I suspect it is understood, in fact it is well known in Melbourne these days, that Mr Costello has been strongly advised by all the key players in the Liberal Party in Victoria that he should distance himself from Mr Kroger and seek his advice elsewhere. This is a well-known fact. It is a shame that Mr Costello seems so reluctant to accept this political advice.

speech.para: Mr Kroger's declining influence on the Liberal Party and the broadening of his attempts to gain some sort of predatory advantage, in terms of commercially provid ing advice to government about the privatisation of the ABC's Online service, has shown that he has acted entirely separately—and we acknowledge this—from his responsibilities as a member of the board of the ABC. He has not consulted with the managing director. He has not consulted with the chairman of the board. He has not sought to raise these issues with the board. He has sought to obtain some cheap publicity for himself which one might suggest was fully supported by Mr Costello—in fact pre-organised with Mr Costello, because it reflects the Liberal Party's deep and abiding hatred of the ABC. It also suggests to me his clear intention to punish the Liberal Party by his continued attempts to present himself as the great powerbroker within that organisation.

Mr Costello ought to make a clean break with this man. He should do the country a favour, do the Liberal Party a favour, and get out of his relationship with Mr Kroger. Mr Packer ought to do much the same himself, because the links there are quite clearly unproductive. Mr Kroger has not delivered what he claimed he would be able to deliver. He has not been able to deliver on so many occasions now. One trusts he will not be able to deliver on this. One simply has to acknowledge that this proposal does not make any sense at all. I hope that, like many of his other financial adventures, it too will fail. The attempt to privatise the ABC's Internet service is ill judged and, given Mr Kroger's membership of the ABC board, I would have thought he would have at least understood the vital part that the ABC's Internet service now plays in the whole organisation.

Mr Kroger estimates that Online's value is about $500 million. What a preposterous concept that is. The whole point about the value of the ABC is that you cannot put a price on it. That is what makes the ABC such a valuable institution to the rest of the country. You cannot put a price on its integrity, on its impartiality, on its objectivity. What he is proposing is essentially to separate out that fundamental premise that the ABC is above price. It is above purchase. It is not like the rest of the media in this country. It has an independent role free from those sorts of commercial pressures. He is proposing to somehow or other place a dollar value on the integrity of the ABC. What we all accept and respect about the ABC is its integrity. Frankly, we do not see that with regard to the Liberal Party view of what the ABC should be—that is, a commercial outfit just like the others and subject to the same sorts of pressures and open to the same sorts of influences.

The great value of Online is that it is directly linked both to the corporation's future convergence plans and, as I say, the basic integrity of the organisation. You cannot possibly separate those two issues. You cannot possibly separate the integral part of Online from the rest of the ABC. The estimates of its value based on a privatised Online assumes that advertising could be introduced to the service as a whole. This is a concept that I find quite preposterous. Given any understanding of the charter of the ABC—and one would have thought that, as a member of the board of the ABC, Mr Kroger would have at least grasped that proposition—the charter of the ABC precludes the use of advertising for very good reasons.

What we have noticed throughout all of this is that the ABC is increasingly relying upon Online's services. The brochures that I have seen outlining the services that are provided by Online provide another alternative news source to many Australians in regional parts of this country. Those issues are directly put at risk by Mr Kroger's proposal. Frankly, in an era of convergence when the boundaries between radio, TV and the web are blurring, it is simply impossible to extract one aspect of the service delivery from the other. To do so would severely weaken the ABC as a whole and frankly weaken all of those services that are being provided.

I say to you that the idea of advertising in this context is quite reprehensible. What Mr Kroger and the Howard government fail to recognise is that the ABC's primary function is to deliver a high quality service to the Australian people which has the respect and the support of the Australian people. It cannot do so when it is seen as a mere commercial operation. Despite the limited resources that the ABC has at its disposal, it is now quite clearly competing, particularly in the Internet field, very strongly with the rest of the private sector.

This is what is really at risk here. This is what the real question is—that is, the great threat the Liberal Party sees. All the enterprises that have been closed down by this government have been those enterprises that the ABC has embarked upon to expand upon its activities which are perceived to be in direct competition with the private sector. Its news gathering role and its capacity to move out into Australian society has been restricted by this government, a government which quite clearly hates and despises the ABC and all that it stands for.

What we are seeing is a government that frankly is not interested in protecting the viability and the long-term interests of this organisation. That is why we have moved this motion today to try to draw attention to the failure of this government in this regard and to acknowledge that it is very important that the ABC be provided with the opportunity to play a key role in developing and promoting Australian content, Australian media and Australian culture both in this country and abroad.

Mr Kroger as an ABC board member should understand that. He should get his mind above these narrow commercial pursuits and he should concentrate on his responsibilities and ensure that the ABC is protected as a viable organisation. His attempts to link the future of ABC funding to the privatisation of key services clearly spells out what the Liberal Party's plan is. It is totally unacceptable in that policy. What we are seeking in this motion, and I trust that the Senate will be able to support it as a whole, is to reaffirm the great values that have made the ABC a tremendous organisation.

talk.start.para: —A real force for civilisation.

—Yes, it is a very important institution to the culture and to the people of this country. It is deeply appreciated by the people of this country. In relation to the constant vilification of the ABC by this government and that conservative body of thought which thinks that the only views that support its values are the ones that should be given coverage and that commercial values are the only ones that should be promoted, those sorts of values in my judgment should be rejected. The ABC is a very important part of Australian cultural life, and this parliament ought to acknowledge it.

—It is always a joy to be able to follow Senator Carr in a debate in this place. He always leads with his chin and he always allows you to score off him very easily. Indeed, Senator Carr's contribution today highlights the reason why he has been so much the overlooked person, so much the pretender, to the Labor Party front bench. Successive Labor leaders and successive Labor caucuses have said, `With contributions such as that, we will not appoint him to the front bench'—and no wonder.

speech.para: His vitriolic and destructive contribution sought to highlight the failures in others. But I would suggest that it is disingenuous in the extreme to seek to highlight and fabricate so-called failures in other people's lives when one's own political career is a littered expressway of failures. All you have to do is ask the former Labor Premier of Victoria—Senator Carr's home state, his home party—John Cain what he thinks of Senator Carr. We know what he thinks. It is not too nice, is it?

talk.start.para: —What does he think?
—I think he wrote about you in his book, didn't he? He called you stupid or something of that nature, which is unparliamentary—
—Tell us all about it.

—But seeing that you have now invited me to state what was written in a book, I will say so and put it on the record, Senator Carr. The greatest spectacular failure of the left wing in the Australian Labor Party in recent times in Victoria was the successful manoeuvring by the left wing—undoubtedly, Senator Carr was involved—in the dramatic demise of one Theo Theophanous, the former leader of the opposition in the upper house in Victoria. The left wing was making a power play against the right wing leader of the Labor Party in Victoria—a complete and spectacular failure.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. We have listened to this for a few moments—in fact, for some considerable minutes—and I do not think we have heard the ABC or Mr Kroger mentioned yet in this speech. It is nothing but this senator's distorted view of factionalism in the ALP.
—Order! I have listened carefully to previous speeches and they have been quite wide ranging. There is no point of order.

—You always know when you are hitting the mark with the Labor Party because they try to get you off your train of thought by jumping up with a spurious point of order. Mr Theophanous in Victoria is undoubtedly licking his wounds, thinking about the adverse advice—the quite poor advice—that the good Senator Carr gave him in the latest power struggle.

speech.para: I will not go on with the many other political failures of the good senator opposite but, given that sort of track record, it is the height of disingenuousness to try to come into this place and assert failures against a person who is on the ABC board—Mr Kroger, who runs a very successful merchant bank. To try to denigrate that person's business under parliamentary privilege is completely unacceptable.

talk.start.para: —Reprehensible.

—Indeed, reprehensible as well, Senator Coonan. The Democrats also sought to make a contribution in this debate, through Senator Bourne. Most of it was by way of interjection on my friend Senator Tierney but, when it was actually Senator Bourne's turn to make a contribution, there was nothing of substance. Indeed, she seemed to come into this debate like she came into the world—eyes closed and mouth wide open. I would suggest to Senator Bourne and the Democrats that they open their eyes and have a look at what is actually going on in the real world, what the benefits would be to the ABC if certain courses of action were even just considered. Then, after she has taken it in, she might consider opening her mouth and making a more substantive contribution to this debate.

speech.para: She sought to link Mr Kroger as a political appointment in the same fashion as the Labor Party used to stack the ABC board. Failed Labor Premier John Bannon—from your home state of South Australia, Senator Quirke—bankrupted the state of South Australia, had no financial capacity whatsoever and his only record in public life was to bankrupt his home state. So what do his federal mates do? They appoint him to the ABC board. In contradistinction, Mr Kroger has a reputation throughout the business community—well in excess of anything Mr Bannon ever had—and his appointment was on the basis of expertise and capacity. We on this side say that a party membership of itself should not disqualify you in relation to an appointment, but if the only characteristic is your party membership—as with John Bannon—then that is something to be condemned, and we in opposition quite appropriately did that. We condemned some of Labor's appointments because they were only appointments of mates. There was no objective standard by which you could say, with that abysmal track record of John Bannon, that he should have been presiding on the ABC board.

Senator Carr, as I indicated earlier, has this unique capacity to lead with his chin. He told us in the debate—and, indeed, in his motion—that the Senate is called upon to `condemn the anti-ABC ideology'. It is interesting to do an analysis of the news reporting during the last federal election campaign. A very respected body—the Institute of Public Affairs—did an analysis. It showed that, during the whole election campaign, National Nine News was the most balanced; Ten News was, in fact, the least: pro-ALP and anti-coalition comments outnumbered pro-coalition and anti-ALP comments on Nine by a 20 per cent margin, on ABC by 23 per cent, on Seven by 40 per cent and on Ten by 60 per cent.

You could say that is a pretty good record for the ABC, but then you have a look at the detailed figures. I want to read from the Institute of Public Affairs analysis because it is very interesting. Three academics, having done a very detailed and considered study, found with respect to the ABC that:

ABC News made a spectacular U-turn during the campaign. In the first two weeks, it was the least balanced of the networks, favouring ALP policies by 56%. However, during the last three weeks of the campaign, ABC News was the most balanced of the four networks, favouring ALP policies by just 8%.

The shift in the ABC coincided with a number of high-profile events—ABC Radio came under fire for promoting a rock concert called `Howard's End'; an interview with Verity James in which she questioned the Prime Minister about the impact of the GST on the price of heroin;—
I do not think even Senator Bolkus would stoop that low—

and the IPA's first press release critical of ABC-TV coverage. The most dramatic shift on ABC News occurred after week two, when the coverage shifted from being highly favourable towards the ALP (by 120%) to favourable towards the Coalition (by 60%).

If you can see that sort of change within the ABC's national news reporting, assessed and undertaken by independent people studying the issues of the federal election campaign very carefully, you do have to ask the question: how unbiased and how balanced is the ABC? I have to ask Senator Bourne: with all the lovely words about ABC independence and how it is such a great institution in Australian society, how could the ABC, from being so biased at the beginning of an election campaign, have the ability to make this dramatic U-turn halfway through; and why did it make the U-turn? Undoubtedly, it was for the reasons outlined by the Institute of Public Affairs.

talk.start.para: —It is not independent; it is a Liberal front!
—Order, Senator Carr!

—I hope that interjection went into the Hansard , because it indicates that the ALP's overwhelming support of the ABC is motivated by only one thing; that is, the unfortunate bias that certain elements have shown which has been demonstrated by these figures provided by the Institute of Public Affairs. I think the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would do itself a great service if it were to consider the IPA Backgrounder report and learn from it. I believe that in my own home state of Tasmania the ABC is fair and balanced, and I have no quarrels with it.

speech.para: But, having said that, for Senators Carr and Bourne to try to paint the ABC as being a lot better than commercial channels that are somehow tainted because of advertising is, quite frankly, beyond the pale and completely insupportable by the objective evidence. This motion, written by the vitriolic pen of Senator Carr, should not be considered by the Senate. It is inappropriate, it demeans the Senate, and I would urge honourable senators to reject it.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 November 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Can a list of successful amendments to the Company Law Review Bill 1997 be provided; (b) what date were these circulated to the Senate; and (c) what date were they passed by the Senate.

(2) Of the successful amendments, please indicate: (a) those which were foreshadowed in the majority or minority reports on this Bill by the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities in 1996 and March 1998; and (b) what dates drafts of those amendments were supplied in writing to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, and by whom.
(3) Did the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer consult with any business or professional organisations on any draft amendments or amendments circulated to the Senate; if so, on what dates.
(4) When was the Bill introduced into the House of Representatives and the Senate; (b) when was the second reading; and (c) when was the committee stage.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: 1 (a) A list of successful amendments to the Company Law Review Bill is attached. The list was provided by the Table Office of the Department of the Senate and I am advised is the same as the list recorded in the House of Representatives Hansard of 25 June 1998 at page 5458.

1(b)—(4) The Government consulted extensively with business, shareholder organisations and other interested parties on policy issues raised by the elements of the Company Law Review Bill 1997 (the Bill). The substance of the Bill was referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities (the Joint Committee) in 1996 and 1998. The Government considered the Reports of the Joint Committee and its position was represented by the Company Law Review Bill 1997 (the Bill) which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 3 December 1997, and into the Senate on 3 March 1998. Amendments were received and moved during the course of passage of the Bill. The Government was not in a position to consult widely on the text of the amendments moved. The amended Bill was passed on 25 June 1998 and commenced operation on 1 July 1998.
THE PARLIAMENT OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE
Company Law Review Bill 1997
