talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 10 November 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) How many people are currently undertaking some form of voluntary work, not including work for the dole, as part of their obligation to receive unemployment allowances; and (b) can a breakdown of age groups be provided.

(2) What procedure is involved in people having voluntary work included as part or all of their obligation, for example, do they need to have that included under a case management agreement and what about those not under case management.

(3) What, if any, ongoing responsibilities does a person who is involved in approved voluntary work have to Centrelink, for example, do they need to provide information fortnightly to Centrelink regarding their voluntary work or other activities.

(4) What restrictions, if any, are placed on the: (a) type of voluntary work which can be undertaken; (b) duration for which the voluntary work can be undertaken; and (c) amount of voluntary work which can be undertaken.
(5) What monitoring or supervision, if any, is conducted by Centrelink of those undertaking voluntary work as part or all of their obligation for receiving unemployment allowances.
(6) Is voluntary work only approved if it can be shown that it is likely to lead to employment; if so, what criteria are used in this assessment and who makes that assessment.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) There are currently two ways an unemployed person can meet requirements for the receipt of Newstart Allowance or Youth Allowance through voluntary work. These are approved voluntary work involving at least 32 hours of voluntary work per fortnight and, for young people subject to Mutual Obligation, voluntary work of 12 hours a fortnight for 7 out of 13 fortnights.

A total of 17,213 customers as at 13 November 1998 are participating in Mutual Obligation, of those, 10,659 customers are participating in an activity to meet their obligation with 1,687 participating in part time voluntary work, 363 participat ing in a combination of voluntary work and part time work, 944 participating in a combination of voluntary work and/or part time work and/or education and training and 19 are participating in full time voluntary work.

In addition to the above 17,213 Mutual Obligation customers, a total of 2,094 customers aged over 25 years are participating in approved voluntary work. Of these, 61 are participating in Voluntary Work and Paid Work, 369 are participating in Voluntary Work with Agreement, and 1,664 were participating in Voluntary Work with no agreement.
(1) (b) Mutual Obligation customers are aged 18 to 24 years inclusive. There is no age group breakdown available to date for the other 2,094 customers from the over 25 years age group.

(2) Procedures for entering into a period of approved voluntary work vary according to the unemployed person's age, their duration on Newstart Allowance and the length of the period of voluntary work they propose to undertake. No Activity Agreement is required to participate in approved voluntary work for unemployed people aged over 50, or unemployed people who have been in receipt of Newstart Allowance for less than 12 months and who wish to participate in voluntary work for a period of 12 weeks or less. A Newstart Activity Agreement is required for unemployed people aged under 50 who wish to participate in approved voluntary work and who have been in receipt of Newstart Allowance for more than 12 months, people who have been unemployed for between 3 and 12 months and who wish to do more than 12 weeks voluntary work and those subject to Mutual Obligation who choose to do voluntary work to satisfy their requirement. The terms of these Activity Agreements must be negotiated with Centrelink.

(3) Customers in approved voluntary work are deemed to satisfy activity test requirements and are not required to report their job search efforts to Centrelink. However they must continue to lodge their "Application for Payment" form with Centrelink. The approved voluntary work activity is recorded on this form which is lodged on a regular basis by the customer (this can be between two and twelve weekly depending on the customer's particular circumstances). If a customer ceases approved voluntary work, then they are required to notify Centrelink and meet the job search requirements of the activity test.

Young Unemployed people subject to Mutual Obligation who choose to satisfy their requirement through voluntary work, are required to record their participation in voluntary work fortnightly in a Mutual Obligation Jobseeker Diary. This diary is assessed by Centrelink every 12 weeks. These customers must maintain their normal level of job search, which will be verified through the diary and through the lodgement of their "Application for Payment" form with Centrelink every 4 weeks.

(4) (a) All approved voluntary work must be undertaken with a Centrelink approved, not-for-profit, community based organisation with volunteer insurance. Under Mutual Obligation requirements, voluntary work must be undertaken with a community based not-for-profit organisation. Certain types of voluntary work would not be approved by Centrelink.
This includes work:
- that replaces a paid worker;
- undertaken in one's own home, with one's family or for one's own organisation;
- that involves violence towards people or property;
- that does not have a community focus; or
- primarily focused on promoting particular religious or political views.
(4) (b) Unemployed people aged over 50 may participate in approved voluntary work of an unlimited duration.

Unemployed people aged under 50 who have been in receipt of Newstart Allowance for between 3 and 12 months can participate in approved voluntary work for a period of up to 12 weeks without the need to negotiate a Newstart Activity Agreement with Centrelink.
Approval to participate in longer periods of approved voluntary work must be negotiated as part of a Newstart Activity Agreement.

Approval for unemployed people aged less than 50 will not normally be given for a period exceeding 12 months in duration. After 12 months participation in approved voluntary work, Centrelink reviews each case to determine whether it would be appropriate to approve a further period of voluntary work.

Unemployed people subject to Mutual Obligation who choose to participate in voluntary work to satisfy their requirement undertake voluntary work for 7 of the 13 fortnights of their Mutual Obligation compliance period.
(4) (c) Participants in approved voluntary work must undertake at least 32 hours per fortnight of voluntary work with a Centrelink approved organisation. There is no upper limit for participation.

Unemployed people subject to Mutual Obligation who choose to participate in voluntary work to satisfy their requirement undertake 12 hours per fortnight voluntary work for 7 of the 13 fortnights of their Mutual Obligation compliance period.

(5) Centrelink monitors customers on approved voluntary work through the lodgement of their "Application for Payment" form. Under the Social Security Act customers must advise of changes to their circumstances (eg cessation of voluntary work) within 7 days.

Unemployed people subject to Mutual Obligation who choose voluntary work to satisfy their requirement will record their participation in voluntary work fortnightly in a Mutual Obligation Jobseeker Diary which is assessed by Centrelink every 12 weeks. Job search efforts will be verified through the diary and the lodgement of their "Application for Payment" form with Centrelink every 4 weeks.

(6) Centrelink does take into consideration whether a period of voluntary work is the best option for an unemployed person when deciding whether to approve a voluntary work placement. However, there is no requirement to demonstrate that a particular voluntary work placement will lead to paid employment for that placement to be approved.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What data was used to calculate the amount of carbon dioxide released by clearing or logging native vegetation in Australia for the greenhouse gas inventory, including the estimated carbon content of each vegetation type for which a separate calculation was made and the references to the scientific studies on which each of the carbon estimates is based.

(2) With reference to native forests: (a) what is the estimated carbon content of: (i) tree trunks, (ii) tree branches and leaves, (iii) tree roots, (iv) understorey vegetation, and (v) soil; (b) on what data are these estimates based; and (c) are they from logged or unlogged forests.
(3) (a) What studies have been mate of the carbon content on unlogged native forests; and (b) could references and details be supplied of when and by whom the work was carried out.

(4) (a) How much carbon is stored in unlogged compared with logged native forests; and (b) if there is no data for comparison, is it thought that unlogged forests contain more carbon and approximately how much more.

(5) (a) How much greenhouse gas is released when an old-growth forest is logged, burnt and converted to an 80 year rotation forest; and (b) what allowance is made for this in the greenhouse gas inventory.

(6) By how much could Australia's greenhouse gas emissions be underestimated because forest carbon data is based on logged forests instead of unlogged ones and/or does not include an estimate of emissions from logging old-growth forests.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1), (2), (3) and (5) The detail of how the emissions inventories are compiled and their construction can be found in Workbook 4.2, Carbon Dioxide from the Atmosphere (1997). This conforms with the requirements laid out in the Revised 1996 Guidelines of the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The Workbook is published by the Australian Greenhouse Office (AGO) and is available at their Website at http://www.greenhouse.gov.au. Supplemental information can also be found in the supporting information to the 1996 Inventory which introduces some updated data and methods to the inventory procedures. The 1996 Inventory also provides the working tables behind the current emissions estimates for 1990 and 1996. The answers to points (1) to (3) of your question can be found in the Workbook and 1996 Inventory with references to source materials provided.

(4) Undisturbed mature forests are generally considered to be in balance between carbon sequestered and emitted. An event, such as fire or harvest which removes carbon from the system generally promotes plant regrowth and leads to net sequestration until a new equilibrium is achieved. The type of disturbance, site growth potential and a variety of other factors will determine the rate at which carbon is sequestered, while the level of carbon storage at the new equilibrium will also be a factor of site growth potential, which is unlikely to change during disturbance.
(6) Forest carbon data (storage) takes account of emissions from clearing and sequestration during regrowth, and therefore, is not considered to be a potential source of estimation error.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

question.para: Was 12,000 kg of the banned chemical pesticide Aldrin imported into Australia between April 1997 and January 1998 from the Indian port of Mumbai; if so: (a) why was it imported; (b) by whom; and (c) what was it used for.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: I have made enquiries on this matter.

Aldrin is prohibited for import into Australia under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, specifically Schedule 9. Goods in Schedule 9 can only be imported if a permit is granted by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. The Australian Customs Service has advised that no declared imports of Aldrin from India occurred between 1 January 1997 and 1 December 1998 (which includes the timespan specified in the question).

The Australian Customs Service and Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry have previously investigated a similar question, based on information provided by Greenpeace in late 1997. In that case it was stated that imports of Aldrin to Australia from India in the years ending March 1996 and March 1997 totalled 27,440 kilograms. The Ministry of Environment and Forests of India and Greenpeace (India) were contacted by Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry officials seeking verification of this information but there has been no response to Greenpeace's claim. Neither the Australia Customs Service nor the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry were able to find any evidence to verify the alleged imports of Aldrin.

Regarding this specific claim, officials in my Department have been unable to find supporting evidence for the claim that 12,000 kilograms of Aldrin was imported from India into Australia between April 1997 and January 1998 (based on the Greenpeace publication `Toxic Legacies; Poisoned—Futures',*November 1998). I would suggest that any further enquires on this matter be directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry who have portfolio responsibility for the control of imports of organochlorine pesticides.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 8 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of recent reports regarding possible export of saltwater crocodile penises to Japan.
(2) Have any requests been received for the approval for the exportation of such crocodile products; if so, will the Government agree to such requests.
(3) Is the Minister aware of the recent reports regarding crocodile products, taken as a result of trophy hunting, being exported.
(4) Have any requests been received for approval for the exportation of such crocodile products.
(5) What is the current situation in relation to the export of crocodile parts as hunting trophies.
(6) Will the Government agree to any requests for export of crocodile hunting trophies.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of reports on the possible exports of crocodile penises to Asia, in particular South-East Asia. I was not aware of reports of possible exports to Japan.
(2) No specific requests have been received for approval for export of penises.
Crocodile farms, once approved under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, are not restricted in the crocodile products which they may sell for export.

(4) No individual requests have been received for approval for export of crocodile products taken as a result of trophy hunting. The Northern Territory Government sought approval for trophy hunting under its management program for crocodiles under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.
(5) Trophy hunting is not permitted under the currently approved crocodile management programs.
(6) The Government does not support trophy hunting and it is not permitted under the currently approved crocodile management programs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) When was the AUSVETPLAN established.
(2) What was the purpose of that plan and on what funding basis was it originally agreed.
(3) When was the AUSVETPLAN last reviewed.
(4) (a) Was that review undertaken by the Australian Animal Health Council.
(b) When did that review commence and (c) when was it completed.
(5) What action followed that review.
(6) What is the membership of the Australian Animal Health Council.
(7) Was any upgrade resulting from that review endorsed by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ); if so, when was it endorsed.
(8) Can details be provided of the changes endorsed by ARMCANZ.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) The concept of a national plan along the lines of AUSVETPLAN was proposed at a seminar in 1985. The structure of the plan was developed over the next few years with the first documents finished in 1989. The first edition of AUSVETPLAN was published in 1991.
(2) The purpose of that plan was to:
- provide a planning structure for the management of an exotic animal disease emergency in which each element has an identifiable place;
- to provide greater coherence and improved recording and indexing of exotic disease plans;

- to avoid gaps and duplication in exotic disease planning and compatibilities of operation and procedures between Commonwealth/State/Territories animal health authorities and Counter-disaster Organisations;
- to improve the technical validity of the underlying assumptions in the development of strategies to combat exotic disease emergencies; and
- to identify deficiencies in technical knowledge required to combat an exotic disease emergency and establish research priorities.

Initial development of AUSVETPLAN was undertaken from existing resources in the former Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Funding of $0.1 million was provided by the Commonwealth in February 1990 to progress the development with the States contributing in kind through membership of writing groups.

(3) Development of AUSVETPLAN continued from publication of the first edition in 1991 with the inclusion of additional disease strategies, industry preparedness manuals and considerable revision to the first edition documents. Publication of the second edition occurred early in 1996. Since then AUSVETPLAN has remained constantly under review by the Veterinary Committee of SCARM, the Australian Animal Health Council and a special editorial group.

(4) (a) Since 1997, the Australian Animal Health Council has contracted the Department of Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry to coordinate continual review, development and maintenance of AUSVETPLAN in conjunction with the States/Territories and industries. This is ongoing, being driven by new disease incidents, scientific developments and a planned program of review of selected documents.
(b) & (c) As stated above the review of AUSVETPLAN is ongoing.

(5) and (7) The second edition of AUSVETPLAN was approved by ARMCANZ in January 1996. ARMCANZ agreed that Veterinary Committee should in future approve technical changes to manuals arising from new knowledge and/or experience, but that significant changes to policy continue to be submitted to ARMCANZ for approval.
(6) The membership of the Australian Animal Health Council consists of the following:

Commonwealth of Australia; State of New South Wales; State of Victoria; State of Queensland; State of South Australia; State of Tasmania; State of Western Australia; Northern Territory; Australian Chicken Meat Federation Inc; Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation Limited; Australian Egg Industry Association Inc; Australian Horse Industry Council; Australian Veterinary Association Limited; Cattle Council of Australia Limited; Pork Council of Australia Limited; Sheepmeat Council of Australia Inc; Wool Council of Australia Inc; Australian Lot Feeders Association; CSIRO.
(8) Since January 1996 ARMCANZ approved a new strategy manual for Japanese encephalitis on 27 February 1998.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Animal Health Council: Policy and Funding Principles
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 362)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 15 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Has a new set of policy and funding principles for pest and disease emergency management been finalised by the Australian Animal Health Council.
(2) (a) When did the process of developing these principles commence; (b) who initiated this process; and (c) when was the process completed.
(3) How will costs of managing such incursions be allocated between the states, the Commonwealth and industry.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The honourable senator's question was referred to the Australian Animal Health Council Ltd (AAHC) for response. The Council is a non-profit public company whose members are the federal and state governments and peak industry organisations. It is the peak animal health body for developing strategic policy advice and for funding of agreed national animal disease programs.

(1) The Council has advised me that work on new cost sharing arrangements for funding of emergency animal disease outbreaks, although well advanced, is currently the subject of more detailed development.
(2) (a) I am advised by the Council that the process of developing new disease emergency funding arrangements commenced in February 1997.
(b) The process was initiated by Commonwealth and State Ministers at the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) meeting in February 1997.

(c) The process has not yet been completed as this is a complex initiative requiring agreement on details between industry and government. ARMCANZ is likely to consider detailed proposals in August 1999.
(3) I am advised by the Council that the principles underlying the proposed arrangements are:
- categorisation of the disease/incursion based upon scientific assessment of its relative impact on human health, trade, animal/plant production and environment;

- a cost sharing formula based on relative responsibilities of the three parties (industry, Commonwealth and state governments) and assessment of apportionment of public/private benefits based on the four considerations above; and

- triggering of the new cost-sharing agreement by relevant portfolio's Ministers and industry based on scientific and technical advice (in the same way the current cost sharing agreement is triggered on advice from the Consultative Committee on Emergency Animal Diseases), but with formal industry involvement.
The details of how some of these principles will work in practice are being considered by AAHC at the moment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What role has the Minister and the Department had in the Food Regulation Review process.
(2) Did the department make a formal submission to that review; if so, can a copy be provided of that review.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided that following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (then the Department of Primary Industries and Energy) was represented on the Food Regulation Review Committee and has contributed to the Review process through formal submissions, provision of comment on issues identified during the initial public comment phase and workshop participation. The Report of the Food Regulation Review, released in August 1998, was provided to the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, his Parliamentary Secretary and the former Minister for Resources.

Subsequent to the release of the Report, the Prime Minister indicated, in a letter to all Premiers and Chief Ministers, that a whole-of-government (Council of Australian Governments (COAG)) response to the Review Report would be developed by COAG Senior Officials. The Prime Minister also asked the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) (which I chair), the Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture (MCFFA) (which I co-chair) and the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council (ANZFSC) to develop an agreed response to the report recommendations for COAG consideration by July 1999.

A joint ARMCANZ/MCFFA High Level Working Group has been established to develop a position on the Food Regulation Review Report for the consideration of ARMCANZ and MCFFA and their Standing Committees. It is anticipated that ARMCANZ and MCFFA will put their position to ANZFSC, in the first instance, to seek an agreed response to take to COAG. ARMCANZ and MCFFA will also consult with industry through the industry peak bodies in developing their response to the Report.

(2) The Department made two formal submissions to the Review, the first during the initial round of public submissions in November 1997 and the second following the release of the Draft Report of the Food Regulation Review for public comment on 27 May 1998. The Department has provided a copy of each of these submissions for the Honourable Senator's information. Copies of the Food Regulation Review Report may be obtained from the Australia New Zealand Food Authority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy establish a transition team to manage the implementation of reforms to the red meat and livestock industries.

(2) (a) When was that team established; (b) who were its members; (c) on how many occasions did it meet; and (d) was the transition team given specific terms of reference; if so, can a copy be provided.
(3) Did the transition team develop a framework for oversight and handling of all issues relating to both safety and hygiene of the whole meat chain; if so, can copies be provided.

(6) Can copies be provided of any reports or other documents relating to this aspect of the transition team's work.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) (a) Industry provided their consent on 17 April 1997 to form the transition team and it held its first meeting on 6 May 1997.
(b) The members of the transition team were as follows:

Cattle Council of Australia; Sheepmeat Council of Australia; Australian Lot Feeders' Association; Australian Livestock Exporters' Council; Australian Meat Council; National Meat Association of Australia ; Meat & Livestock Australia (after the board was appointed on 19 August 1997); Australian Meat Processor Corporation; Australian Livestock Exporters Corporation; Australian Meat & Livestock Corporation; Meat Research Corporation; Freehill, Hollingdale and Page (legal advisors) and representatives of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy's office and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

(c) The transition team held 26 meetings from May 1997 to June 1998, plus numerous other smaller working groups also met to discuss various issues in relation to the new red meat industry arrangements.
(d) Yes. A copy of the Terms of Reference is attached.

(3) Yes. A government and industry partnership called Safemeat was developed to oversight safety and hygiene issues for the whole meat chain. The agreed framework for its operation is included in the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) which is on the internet at the following address:
www.affa.gov.au/dpie/agriculture/meat-livestock/mou/contents.html
A copy of the relevant Schedule of the MoU is attached.

(4) (5) and (6) No. The achievement of efficiency savings in the meat processing chain was not a key part of the transition team's brief. However, the new arrangements have enabled the processing industry to move from providing statutory levies to voluntary contributions which has substantially reduced their costs.

(7) (8) (9) and (10) No. The transition team has not been replaced by a permanent body. The transition team was only established to represent the varied interests of industry bodies and Government in implementing reforms to service delivery mechanisms for meat and livestock industries in Australia within the policy framework set out by the Government.
TRANSITION TEAM FORUM
TERMS OF REFERENCE
Purpose

The purpose of the Transition Team is to represent the varied interests of Industry bodies and Government in implementing reforms to service delivery mechanisms for meat and livestock industries in Australia within the policy framework set out by the Government.
Role

The Transition Team Forum is an important cross linking mechanism which will facilitate a smooth transition from the current Statutory arrangements to the proposed Industry controlled Corporations, while addressing issues of concern to both Industry representative bodies and Government.

Ultimately industry is responsible for grasping the opportunities provided in the meat reform package through development of the most appropriate corporate structure to operate within the boundaries established. This forum will act as a vehicle for ensuring that industry takes full opportunity of this initiative. It provides a mechanism for linking Government needs through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and ensuring minimum standards of accountability required by Parliament for Commonwealth Appropriations are met.

Industry has given the Transition Team members the responsibility and the authority to negotiate on behalf of their respective body/members and to deal with the details associated with implementation of the meat reforms. This may need to be achieved on an ad referendum basis. That is, Industry and where necessary Government representatives, have been given the authority to negotiate on behalf of their respective bodies/members, but with the final position may need to be approved by the respective body/members.
Principles
Important principles for the operation of this Forum are as follows:
. it is the responsibility of all members of this Forum to work constructively and collaboratively in achieving a co-ordinated approach to implementing meat and livestock reforms

. the Forum will recognise that there are substantial differences between Industry representatives and Government in relation to the diversity and complexity of management issues which need to be taken into account in the decision making processes.
. this Forum will consult on decisions and their implementation in a full and timely manner
. decisions will be made in an open and transparent manner
Schedule 4—Safemeat
Commencement date 27 April 1998
1 Parties
1. Peak Industry Councils (other than ALEC)
2. MLA
3. The Commonwealth
2 Definitions in addition to those in Statement of Principles
States/Territories Meat and Livestock Authority means the State or Territory government organisation in a State or Territory with the responsibility for registering and overseeing industry standards.
3 Purpose of Schedule
To describe the arrangements for the establishment and operation of Safemeat.
4 Detail
4.1 Membership
(a) The members of Safemeat will be:
(1) the Secretary, Department of Primary Industries and Energy: to represent the Commonwealth and facilitate management and implementation of Commonwealth responsibilities;
(2) the CEO from a State Department of Agriculture/Primary Industries: to represent States/Territories and facilitate management and implementation of States/Territories responsibilities;
(3) the Chairperson from a States/Territories Meat and Livestock Authority to represent States/Territories Meat and Livestock Authorities;
(4) the Chairpersons/Presidents of each of CCA, SCA, ALFA, AMC and NMA: to be responsible for actions needed to ensure hygienic and safe product throughout each industry sector they represent; and

(5) the Commonwealth Chief Veterinary Officer (CVO ), who also is in charge of the Commonwealth Office of Food Safety: the CVO has direct links into the human health network and has a key responsibility for international market access negotiations and international organisations such as the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE).

(b) Each member will have the right to nominate a person to act on their behalf in any of the activities carried out or to be carried out by or through Safemeat. The person must be senior and able to take decisive action on behalf of the government or industry sector they represent.
(c) The members will appoint the chairperson of AMC or the chairperson of NMA to be chairperson of Safemeat and determine the period for which that person will hold office.

(1) The chairperson of MLA will be a full participant in discussions and MLA will provide back-up support by way of research, analysis and advice. Services which MLA may be asked to provide to underpin the operations of Safemeat will be delivered in an efficient and cost effective manner.
(2)The chairperson of MLA will have the right to nominate a senior person to act on their behalf who has authority to take any decisive action which may be required.

(e) Other persons may be called upon from time to time to have direct and full participation in Safemeat, depending on the issues involved. This applies particularly to the Commonwealth or States/Territories Chief Medical Officers.
4.2 Role
The role of Safemeat will be:
(a) to work with the objective of establishing world best practice in ensuring the safety of meat;
(b) to ensure each industry sector implements sound management systems to ensure safe and hygienic product is delivered to the market place;
(c) to ensure adequate and nationally consistent government standards and regulations relating to meat safety and hygiene;

(d) to ensure that effective crisis management strategies are in place by the appropriate industry sectors and, to this end, ensure that there is a fully integrated and effective communications network; and
(e) to monitor industry meat safety performance.
4.3 Operations

(a) Safemeat will operate as a working partnership of Commonwealth and States/Territories government interests and industry sector interests, with each participant responsible for reporting to their respective government or industry sector and ensuring that outcomes required of them are delivered.
(b) Safemeat participants will appoint working groups which will have direct responsibility for carrying out work required and delivering outcomes.
(c) The secretariat will be selected by competitive tender.
(d) Members will meet at least 4 times a year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What impact will the Government's goods and services tax package have on the price of wine: (a) per 750 ml bottle of wine `Made in Australia'; (b) per 750 ml bottle of wine `Product of Australia'; (c) per 750 ml bottle of imported wine; (d) per 750 ml of cask wine `Made in Australia'; (e) per 750 ml of cask wine `Product of Australia'; and per 750 ml of imported cask wine.
(2) Millilitre for millilitre, will the package advantage average prices of cask wine as against bottled wine; if so, by how much and why.
(3) Has the Minister been approached by Tasmanian vignerons concerned by the impact of the package on sales of their produce; if so, what action is to be taken to assuage those concerns.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The reforms to alcohol taxation do not distinguish between domestic and imported products. Incorporating both the direct and indirect impact of tax changes, including reductions in industry costs, a medium priced bottle of wine, either domestic or imported, is expected to rise by between 2 and 3 per cent, and cask wine is expected to rise by no more than the general CPI impact of the tax reform package, ie 1.9 per cent.

(2) As noted above, the price of cask wine is expected to increase by no more than the estimated general price increase associated with tax reform, ie 1.9 per cent; bottled wine prices are expected to rise by between 2 and 3 per cent. The difference is due to the higher product value of bottled wine over cask wine, and the higher retail margins on bottled wine compared to cask wine.
(3) Tasmanian vignerons have made representations on tax reform. These concerns are being examined.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Forestry and Conservation:

question.para: (1) What was the total volume of woodchips from broadleaved forests exported from Australia in the 1997-98 financial year.
(2) Of this: (a) what volume came from native forests; (b) what volume from eucalypt plantations; and (c) what volume from any other source, (please specify).

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Forestry and Conservation has provided the following answer to the Honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1 and 2) Due to changes in regulations under the Export Control Act (1982), this information is no longer available from the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. With the introduction of Regional Forest Agreements in Tasmania, East Gippsland and the Central Highlands (both in Victoria), it is no longer a requirement to hold an export licence to export material from these regions, and no longer a requirement that they report their exports to the Department.

Similarly, the removal of plantation controls in Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia and New South Wales, makes licensing for the export of materials sourced from plantations in these States unnecessary. It is therefore no longer a requirement that exporters report details of wood chip exports sourced from plantations to the Department.
However, the Australian Bureau of Statistics is able to provide some statistics on wood chip exports.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the current dollar value as a carbon bank (ie a permanent carbon store) of each of the following vegetation types (per hectare and total in Australia): (a)old-growth native forests; (b)logged native forests; (c)eucalypt plantations; and (d)pine plantations.
(2) What markets or transactions were used to derive the values for carbon credits used to calculate the amounts in paragraph (1).
(3) (a) How is the value of stored carbon expected to change over time; and (b) What is the basis for this estimate.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Forestry and Conservation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There is no data available on the dollar value of the carbon sequestered in Australian forests. However, the physical quantities of carbon in Australian forests have been estimated in studies undertaken by the Bureau of Rural Sciences. The following are based on the results of these studies:
(a) Because of the lack of available data there is no estimate of carbon contained in the old growth component of native forests.
(b) The carbon pool in productive Medium and Tall Eucalypt Forests is estimated at 3 000 million tonnes.
(c) The carbon pool in hardwood plantations is estimated at 19 million tonnes.
(d) The total carbon pool in Australia's softwood plantations is estimated at 108 million tonnes.

The above categories do not cover all forest types. For instance the carbon pool in woodlands is estimated at more than 7 000 million tonnes. The total carbon pool in Australian forests is estimated at 13 136 million tonnes.

(2) There is currently no regular trading in carbon credits in Australia and therefore no market price on which to base a calculation of the value of forest carbon in Australia. Some preliminary trading in carbon credits has, however, taken place. In NSW, Pacific Power has embarked on a trial of carbon trading by purchasing the carbon rights for 10 years to 1000 hectares of the State's hardwood plantations. Delta Electricity has also provided land for softwood plantations in exchange for the carbon rights. Details of the prices paid in any such transactions are likely to be commercially confidential.
The Government has no plans at present to introduce a domestic emissions trading system, though it is carrying out in depth investigations of whether such a system would be feasible or desirable.
(3) The value of stored carbon will not be known until a regular carbon trading scheme is established.

subdebateinfo.title: Regional Forest Agreement: Commonwealth Financial Liabilities
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 372)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: "With reference to the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998:
(1) Was any assessment made of the potential exposure of the Commonwealth to financial liabilities resulting from the compensation provisions in regional forest agreements; if not, why not.

(2) What is the Commonwealth's potential liability, under each regional forest agreement, in compensation payments to affected parties if the Commonwealth takes action at any time during the 20-year life of each regional forest agreement to `protect the environment and heritage values in native forests'.

(3) How much compensation would the Commonwealth have to pay if its actions directly or indirectly curtailed forestry or mining operations in areas covered by the regional forest agreement, as a result of Australia's obligation under the Climate Change Convention to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

(4) How much compensation would the Commonwealth have to pay if an action by it resulted in curtailment of forestry or mining operations in areas covered by the regional forest agreement for any of the following purposes:
(a) nomination or listing of an area under world heritage, for either cultural or natural values;
(b) nomination or listing of an area under the Ramsar Convention or any other international treaty;
(c) protection of species or communities that are found to be threatened during the next 20 years;
(d) protection of the quantity or quality of water in a water catchment; and
(e) flood mitigation."

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Forestry and Conservation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Regional Forest Agreements (RFAs) include compensation provisions in order to maximise certainty in forest areas covered by the agreements. In the interests of such certainty, RFAs set out the processes by which any compensation liability will be assessed, agreed and paid. Further, Clause 7(1) of the Regional Forest Agreement Bill 1998 would ensure that the Commonwealth is liable for any compensation it is required to pay to a State under compensation provisions contained in an RFA in force at the time the Act commences or at the time the RFA commences, whichever is later. The Bill would also ensure that any Commonwealth liability under this subsection, which may be incurred when an RFA is in force, remains even though the RFA may subsequently be terminated or expire, and that compensation payments liable to be paid by the Commonwealth to a State under Clause 7(1) may be recovered as a debt and are payable from funds appropriated by Parliament.

Any such Commonwealth compensation liability could only arise from a Commonwealth breach of an undertaking in an RFA. The Commonwealth has no intention of breaching any such undertakings. As any potential Commonwealth compensation liability could only be assessed in the light of the specific nature and circumstances of any alleged Commonwealth breach of an RFA, it is not possible to assess the extent of any potential liability that may arise in relation to the operation of RFA compensation provisions.
(2) See response to (1) above.
(3) See response to (1) above.
(4) See response to (1) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Government's commitment that electricity retailers and other large buyers will be required to source an additional 2 per cent from renewable or specified waste-product energy sources:
(1) (a) What technologies and energy sources will be permitted within the definition of `renewable or specified waste-product energy sources'; and (b) which ones will be excluded.
(2) Can it be confirmed that technologies to improve the efficiency of fossil fuel use or to use wastes from fossil fuels, in particular coal, will not be allowed in the 2 per cent target.

(3) (a) Has the `competitive model' used in Britain (where its renewables target has been met through least cost tendering) resulted in the demise of the british renewables industry; and (b) will this model be ruled out for Australia.

(4) (a) Can it be confirmed that key objectives of the implementation mechanism for the 2 per cent renewables target in Australia will be to expand jobs and industry in the renewables sector; if not, why not; (b) consequently, will the assessment of implementation options include a comparative estimate of the jobs and industry development that would flow from each option; if not, why not; and (c) will this assessment be made public; if not, why not.

(5) Will the implementation mechanism include: (a) separate tranches for different technologies; and (b) a phased approach to the 2 per cent target with milestones (for example 0.5 per cent by 2002 etc); in each case, if not, why not.
(6) When will the implementation of the 2 per cent target begin.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (b) This is yet to be determined. Implementation options for the 2 per cent target are currently being considered by a technical working group comprising representatives of Commonwealth and State/Territory governments and industry. The working group has consulted widely with affected parties. The working group reports to the Greenhouse Energy Group, which in turn reports to the Council of Australian Governments High Level Group on Greenhouse (CoAG HLG). It is expected that the CoAG HLG will consider final implementation options before mid-1999.
(2) This is yet to be determined. See answer to question 1.
(3) (a) I am unable to comment on whether the competitive model used in Britain to introduce renewables into electricity supply "resulted in the demise of the British renewables industry".
(b) This is yet to be determined. See answer to question 1.
(4) (a) The 2% target has multiple objectives to:
. accelerate the uptake of renewable energy in grid-based applications, so as to reduce greenhouse gas emissions;
. as part of the broader strategic package to stimulate renewables, provide an on-going base for the development of commercially competitive renewable energy; and
. contribute to the development of internationally competitive industries which could participate effectively in the burgeoning Asian energy market.
The measure's second objective is focused on supporting the development of a robust domestic renewable energy industry.

(b) Economic and financial analysis undertaken to determine final implementation options will consider the possible employment outcomes of the 2 per cent target within the renewable energy industry. A study into the Potential of the Australian Renewable Energy Industry to Expand Capacity to Meet the 2% Target has already been commissioned.

(c) The results of the study into the capacity of Australia's renewable energy industry to respond to the target will be publicly available, through the Australian Greenhouse Office's website when it is completed. The results of any economic and financial analysis will be considered in making final decisions on implementation options.
(5) (a) This is yet to be determined. See answer to question 1.
(b) This is yet to be determined. See answer to question 1.

(6) This is yet to be determined. See answer to question 1. It is recognised that the scale of investment required for achievement of the measure argues for early implementation to assist long-term planning.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What Commonwealth government programs specifically fund renewable energy research.

(2) Can funding from the Greenhouse Office be used to fund research,not commercialisation; if so, can a list be provided of the research projects that have been funded in 1998 and the amount allocated to each; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Renewable energy research is supported through Government funding for
. support to the Co-operative Research Centres, such as the Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy and other energy-related CRCs;
. The R&D Start program administered by the Department of Industry, Science and Resources—substantial funding is available under the program for energy related projects;

. funding of the CSIRO, particularly through specific programs being run within its Energy Technology and Forestry and Forestry products divisions, and other research institutions including universities; and
. the 125% tax concession on company R&D.
The Government is also

. through the 2% renewables target, establishing a major incentive for energy providers to increase private sector support for the research, development and commercialisation of renewable energy technologies; and
. supporting an ethanol R&D program and the construction of an ethanol pilot plant to demonstrate Australian technologies, especially for the production of renewable transport fuels.

(2) The Australian Greenhouse Office is responsible for the delivery of grants and venture capital programs worth more than $60m over 5 years to facilitate the commercialisation and application of renewable energy technologies.
This assistance is being provided through three programs:
. Renewable Energy Showcase;
. Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program (originally announced as the Renewable Energy Technology Commercialisation Loans and Grants); and
. Renewable Energy Equity Fund (originally announced as the Renewable Energy Innovation Investment Fund).
These programs are not designed to support research projects, although some incidental research may be undertaken in the process of demonstrating a technology and proving its commercial potential.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Animal Health Council: Recommendation Implementation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 383)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 15 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the status of the `strategic priorities for animal health' prepared by the Australian Animal Health Council (AAHC).
(2) What are the major recommendations contained in the strategy.
(3) Who is responsible for implementing each recommendation.
(4) What is the timetable for the implementation of each recommendation.
(5) Can a copy be provided of the AAHC report.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The honourable senator's question was referred to the Australian Animal Health Council Ltd for response. The Council is a non-profit public company whose members are the federal and state governments and peak industry organisations. It is the peak animal health body for developing strategic policy advice and for funding of agreed national animal disease programs.

(1) The Council has advised me that the status of `Strategic Priorities for Animal Health in Australia 1998—2003' is current. The plan was completed in 1998. Some of the strategies are now completed and others are in various stages of implementation.

(2) I am advised that the plan is a comprehensive document containing key programs and strategic priorities for Australia's animal health services for the next five years (1998—2003). A detailed rationale for the recommended strategic directions is contained in the plan. Strategic priorities in the plan have been developed under the following categories:
- legislation and administration;
- diagnosis, surveillance and reporting;
- integration of the private sector;
- animal welfare; food safety and residues; and
- emergency preparedness.
(3) The Council has advised me that responsibility for each of the actions under the strategic priorities is detailed in the plan.
(4) The Council has advised me that target dates for each of the actions under the strategic priorities are detailed in the plan.
(5) I understand that the Council has directed a copy of the plan to the honourable Senator's office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry upon notice, on 15 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What was the cost of eradicating avian influenza in New South Wales.
(2) (a) What was the allocation of the cost between the Commonwealth, the states and the industry; and (b) on what basis was that allocation determined.
(3) Has compensation been paid to affected producers.
(4) (a) What level of compensation has been paid; (b) how many producers received compensation; and (c) how was the level of compensation determined.

(5) Has `country freedom' status from the disease been reinstated in Australia; if so, when did that occur; if not: (a) when will Australia be given `country freedom' status; and (b) why has the declaration been delayed.
(6) Are all countries now accepting poultry products from New South Wales; if not: (a) which countries are still refusing product from New South Wales, and (b) what is the basis of their refusal.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The cost of the Virulent avian influenza outbreak in New South Wales in 1997 eligible for reimbursement under the "Commonwealth/States cost sharing agreement for the eradication of certain exotic animal diseases" (CSA) totalled $4.445 million. This is subject to audit. This does not include the costs of salaries or wages of staff who are, or would be, employed by the responsible Commonwealth, State or Territory organisations, irrespective of the disease emergency who were deployed on, or in connection with, the eradication campaign.
(2) (a) The allocation of the $4.445 million subject to the CSA was:

(b) The total costs are apportioned between the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories in accordance with Sections 13 and 18 of the Commonwealth/States cost-sharing agreement endorsed by the Agricultural Industries and Food Committee of the Standing Committee of Agriculture and Resource Management (SCARM) on 3 January, 1996. The allocation between the States and Territories is based on the three-year mean of State/Territory laying hen numbers and poultry slaughterings.
(3) Yes.

(4) (a) $2,167,965; (b) 5; and (c) The level of compensation is based on the "farm gate value" in accordance with the Commonwealth/States cost sharing agreement, with the endorsement of the Consultative Committee for Emergency Animal Diseases of SCARM. Independent valuation of livestock and property was undertaken where appropriate.

(5) `Country freedom' status was reinstated for Australia on 13 June 1998 in accordance with the guidelines of the Office International des Epizooties (OIE) International Animal Health Code chapter for highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI).
(6) In relation to the effects of the outbreak of Virulent avian influenza in New South Wales on exports of Australian poultry products, no trade restrictions by importing countries remain in place.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 17 July 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Is the Minister aware of continuing concerns being expressed by a broad range of Aboriginal people in the Gammon and North Flinders Ranges region over the environmental and cultural impacts of development of the proposed Beverley uranium mine site; (b) how are these concerns being addressed; and (c) does the Minister intend to consult with dissenting Aboriginals in the area.

(2) (a) Is the Minister aware that the proposed mining technique and leaching agent (acid leaching) being proposed for the Beverley site is no longer permitted to be used in commercial operations in the United States of America (USA) because of documented adverse impacts; and (b) can an explanation be provided as to why South Australia should be afforded less environmental protection or regard than in New Mexico.

(3) (a) Can the volume of uranium extracted to date from the `trial' mining operation at Beverley be clarified; (b) where is the uranium currently stored; and (c) how did it get to this location and who owns this product.

(4) Can clarification be given in relation to persistent anecdotal reports that exist in the region that the trial in-situ leaching operation conducted by Heathgate Resources at Beverley has experienced significant difficulties and irregularities in relation to pressure and containment and that these difficulties have required the attention of South Australian and Commonwealth agencies and international personnel.

(5) Can an explanation be provided as to why the current licensing arrangements make no requirement on Heathgate to restore ground water quality to pre-mining levels, unlike the situation in the USA, and indeed allows the company to directly discharge acid, mine and radioactive waste materials directly to the aquifer.

talk.start.para: —The amended answer to the honourable senator's question, which updates the previous answer, is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) I understand that the concerns of the local Aboriginal people have been addressed by the proponent and that agreements have been signed with all four native title claimants to the area. (b) The EIS and assessment process has provided a means of exposing all aspects of the project to public review and consultation. (c) Consultations were held with local Aboriginal people during the assessment process by the proponent and State agencies.
(2) (a) Acid leaching as a mining technique is not banned in the USA.

Most uranium mines use the in-situ leach mining technique in conjunction with an alkali leach, because the generally high levels of carbonates make acid leachates inefficient in the groundwater associated with the mines; (b) The environment protection for the Beverley mine is of the highest standard. The geology of US uranium deposits is not suitable for acid leaching and an alkali solution is used instead. Nevertheless ISL mines are required to be carefully monitored and controlled whatever type of leachate is used.

(3) (a) Approximately 32 tonnes of uranium oxide stored in 200 litre steel drums; (b) In a secure enclosure within the processing area at Beverley; (c) Uranium produced is owned by the South Australian government.

(4) I understand that the trials at Beverley have been very successful in their stated purpose of determining optimum operating conditions including environmental matters. There have not been any significant difficulties and irregularities in relation to pressure and containment. I understand that the only international personnel involved are engaged by Heathgate Resources which is US owned.

(5) The groundwater at the Beverley mineralised zone aquifer is highly saline and contains uranium and radon with no potential use for people or stock. In contrast, several US ISL mines operate in or immediately adjacent to aquifers from which nearby communities draw drinking water supplies. If approval is given for the proposed Beverley mine final conditions will be determined as part of the EIS process. Compared to pre-mining levels, radioactivity of the water in the mine zone will not change after mining. Heathgate Resources is proposing to use a technique known as `groundwater sweep', where water from a mined out area is exchanged with groundwater from the next area to be mined. This results in a reduction of acidity in the mined out area. However, there will still be an elevation in the amount of some metals in the aquifer which could take up to 20 years to return to pre-mining levels.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: A question (Hansard page 421) regarding:
. Industry cost reductions of $10 billion each year due to the Government's tax reform package.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Industry costs will be reduced by an average of 3.2 per cent. The GST will allow governments to reduce the tax burden on Australian business by more than $10 billion each year from 2001-02.
The industry cost reductions stem from:
. the removal of the wholesale sales tax (WST);
. diesel excise reforms; and
. the abolition of State and Territory taxes such as financial institutions duty, debits tax and most stamp duties on business activities.

The most significant reduction in industry costs comes from the abolition of the WST. The current WST is a hidden tax. It is a tax on tax that increases the cost of producing goods and services, including exports.
